Using a series of controlled demolition charges you are able to create a new chamber to drain the water away. The plan works flawlessly and you recover the high quality armour fully intact.
In an attempt to drain the chamber you accidentally trigger a cave-in; the chamber is now blocked by fallen rocks and debris. Whatever was in there is likely to remain buried, forever.
Only a fool would disturb the dead. The best thing for everyone - living and dead - is that you leave. Now, without further ado.
There are a series of tracks leading away from the graveyard to the North. You follow them and find they lead to a cave filled with hastily-buried chests.
It seems whoever buried the bodies has long since departed and it's unlikely you'd be able to track them down now anyway.
One of the corpses is bedecked in finery and still clutches his weapons. A powerful magical aura emanates from the grave.
As the corpses are uncovered a strange miasma seeps from among the graves. You should not have disturbed the dead. Now you will pay the price!
Your retainer detects a faint magical signature coming from one of the graves. You dig it up and find a corpse clutching a powerful magical item.
There are no traces of magic on these graves, it must've been a trick of the light and nothing more. Let the dead rest in peace.
While the treasures are tempting, no one in their right mind would leave them unguarded, surely?
You take as many of the artefacts as you dare and run from the vault. The desire for Lustrian artifacts means you will be able to command a high price for them.
You take as many of the artefacts as you can carry and exit the vault. In the light of day you quickly realise that they are nothing more than worthless reproductions.
Ignoring the tempting artefacts, your retainers soon find chests filled to the brim with gold, hidden at the back of the vault.
As your men begin their search, there is the sound of giant gears whirring into life. The entrance to the vault is suddenly blocked by a huge boulder!
The vault is likely riddled with traps! You cautiously back out, informing your retainers to mark the location on the map - most treasure hunters are always happy to pay for information such as this.
The vault is likely riddled with traps! You cautiously back out, informing your retainers to mark the location on the map. Sadly, you are unable to sell the information.
It's best to act quickly and decisively if you want to hold on to your sanity! You burn the shrine to the ground; the embers cackle and hiss as the makeshift structure falls apart.
It doesn't take too long to find someone with the power and will to cleanse the taint of Chaos. They safely purge the basement, as well as several other nearby relics.
You employ a supposed 'expert' to cleanse the shrine. However, the charlatan does little more than set it on fire and demand an extortionate fee!
Some things are best left untouched. In fact, this is the very epitome of something you shouldn't touch. Sensibly, you seal the basement and leave.
Although you resist the corruption of Chaos, others in your party are not so strong. Weaker minds are drawn to its power and are soon prostrate before the altar, praying to Slaanesh.

On closer inspection, it turns out that the shrine is extremely rudimentary and devoid of corruption. In fact, it's unlikely that Slaanesh even noticed it was built! You dismantle the altar with ease and smash the parts.
The power of Slaanesh is hard to resist. A tide of twisted thoughts and desires fills your head and you soon find yourself bent in prayer before the shrine of the Dark Prince.
Pushing a retainer down the tunnel ahead of you doesn't look good in front of the others, however practical. You decide not to investigate the tunnel and leave, with haste.
From deep within the tunnel comes a rumbling growl, followed by a strange beast that attacks without warning; battle ensues. Fortunately, you are able to slay the beast and escape unscathed.

From deep within the tunnel comes a deafening howl, followed by a savage, many-tentacled beast that attacks without warning. In the ensuing fight, several of your party are badly wounded but all manage to escape.

You ask for volunteers and soon a scouting party is deployed. They discover a hidden treasure deep within the tunnel. Although it takes awhile for them to retrieve it, the hoard proves to be well worth the wait.

You wait for hours, but the scouts never return; it's looking like some foul luck indeed has befallen your retainers. The rest of your party are clearly spooked, so you leave without a backward glance.
Nothing good can come from exploring these tunnels, except maybe a slow, painful death as the lunch of something deeply unpleasant. You collapse the tunnel entrance and walk away.
Your retainers are a tad overzealous collapsing the tunnel, and some of your supplies are caught in the blast. Angered, you leave the idiots to their fate and leave the building.
The Dwarfs waste their own time and that of others with such things. You have no use for their strange follies, so walk away.
The expert you hired is able to safely crack open the automaton and study it. It doesn't appear to serve any useful purpose but there are those willing to pay handsomely for a curio such as this.
After a few days you still haven't heard from the expert you hired. When you send someone to investigate, they discover a corpse and bloody automaton tracks leading from the house.
You never work out what the purpose of the device is, but nevertheless manage to find someone willing to buy it. Oh well, there's one born every minute!
You manage to find someone willing to buy the device, but it explodes during the trade. A lucky escape - fortunately only the buyer is killed this time.
The automaton falls over on its side and explodes, destroying a nearby wall. The explosion reveals a chest full to the brim with exactly the sort of treasure you have been seeking all along!

As far as you can tell the wretched thing has no purpose. You order a retainer to take the biggest axe they can find and dismember the automaton, making as much noise and mess as possible in the process.
Sometimes, this is how it goes. Not all hunts are successful and the wise know when they are beaten. Perhaps a fortune will present itself further down the road?
After a thorough search it is clear that there are no spoils to be had. You turn your attention to the tracks but it is soon obvious that they are too faded to follow.
Determined to find something, you hire a group of skilled - and expensive - treasure hunters to search through the ruins. They are soon forced to admit that they too are unable to find anything.

Following the tracks you come across a small band of treasure hunters encamped a short distance away, their wagons bursting with chests. You chase them off with ease and claim their haul for yourself.
The tracks are confusing and double back on themselves several times. In the bewilderment, you get turned around and eventually lose the trail altogether.
A travelling merchant passes through the ruins and you capture and question him. He offers useless rumours and little else. You decide to relieve him of his goods to teach him a lesson.
You setup a makeshift barricade on the edge of the town and await for your predecessors to return. After days of fruitless waiting you finally admit defeat and leave.
There's no reason to engage with desperate people; oft-times, such schemes come to naught anyway. You decide to leave them to their seditious talk and walk away quietly.
Surprised by and failing to recognise you, they listen and agree to trade some of their excellent-looking weapons for supplies. The equipment turns out to be of superior quality.

Your friendly offer of trade breaks the ice. The dissenters agree to trade weapons for supplies. Unfortunately, their offerings are inferior, but a deal is a deal; at least the rebels are deprived of arms!
Providence has brought you here to silence these agitators afore they can act! Their screams fill the air as the barn burns to the ground. Your people feel much safer in their beds.
Ha! Clearly these rabble-rousers thought themselves safe to speak freely of their treachery. The barn burns to the ground and no one escapes; only the smell of charred flesh remains.
You take the rebels completely by surprise. Overwhelmed, they surrender and turn over their weapons in return for their miserable lives. Naturally, you have them killed anyway.
Entering the barn, you challenge the survivors and a stand-off ensues. Enraged by your arrogance, they refuse to surrender. Rallying together, they defame you as a tyrant.
The other party are not known to you, and they are carrying a variety of very sharp-looking weapons with them. Plunder is never worth losing your life over; you leave empty handed.
You find a few discarded trinkets that may have some worth, but have the sinking feeling that the main hoard has been lost to the strangers. You win some, you lose some.
You don't manage to find anything of interest. It seems the strangers got here first and cleaned the place out. You curse the skies and leave.

Unusually, the scavengers welcome your offer and you join them in their search. Whilst working alongside the strangers you manage to find a hidden vault of treasure. Now, if only there was a way to avoid splitting the profits with them...?
Your gut feeling was correct! You join up with the scavengers to search the ruins. However, after a few hours they disappear, along with some of your belongings!
At the first sign of trouble the scavengers flee, leaving all their belongings. Some beings are just not cut for high-energy, high-stakes work such as this!
You manage to chase off the scavengers with ease. It's unfortunate, but not a total surprise to find that they hadn't located anything of value either.
Leaving well alone be may be the most sensible course of action here. It is impossible to truly kill a Daemon of Nurgle, you would only invoke its ire.
The Daemon tells the truth! Your warriors are all replenished by the healing properties of the tears. But of course, you always knew this boon would come at a terrible cost...
Obviously, Daemons of Chaos are not be trusted! Slaying the creature wipes the nauseating taint of its putrefaction from the ruins.
Cutting the foul, sickening flesh causes great gouts of pus and slime to gush forth, tainting the earth with its repellent corruption. Stand well back!
The Daemon was trying to distract you - a sleight of repulsive, pustulating hand, no less! Hidden beneath its foetid flesh you find chests stuffed with treasure.
Whilst lifting the flaps of pallid flesh one of your retainers accidentally cuts the Daemon, causing great gouts of pus and slime to gush forth, tainting the ground with foul corruption.
Upon the altar are pages that appear to be from one of the Great Necromancer's Nine Books! The place is clearly cursed! Get out while you still can!
The shrine goes up in flames, taking the rest of the building with it. Better safe than sorry - you torch the surrounding area also before moving on.
The shrine goes up in flames, taking the rest of the building with it. You torch the surrounding area also before moving on – better safe than sorry!
The shrine goes up in flames, but as the dust settles a ghostly figure rises from the ashes. This is not the result you had in mind...
Following a complicated ritual you are able to cleanse the shrine and remove the taint of the Undead from the room. You no longer have the feeling that you are under observation.
Following a complicated ritual you are able to cleanse the shrine and remove the taint of the Undead from the room. You no longer have the feeling that you are under observation.
The shrine is powerful and the cleansing ritual is time-consuming and costly. However, once it is complete you are able to remove all the artefacts found within.
Embedded in the centre of the shrine you find a powerful magical item. You are surprised when you are able to easily lift it free.

There is nothing of value within the shrine. During the course of the search you begin to feel different; the room starts to swim and your temperature soars! Clearly, you are now in the grip of a dark and terrible curse!
Sometimes there's no way out but to reach for your purse. You begrudgingly pay the creatures and leave with your life intact, if not your dignity.
By their very nature, Skaven love to talk, so you manage to keep them busy until your scouts return. As they ride into the clearing the Skaven are surprised and panic, turn their tails and run away!

Skaven are not the best conversationalists and you soon run out of things to say. You stall for as long as you can, but the scouting party never returns. Your only option is to pay the Skaven if you wish to live.
Ratmen are neither rats nor men; you easily slay the Skaven. Their bodies are still littering your camp when the scouting party returns.
You fight bravely but are soon overpowered by the Skaven's overwhelming numbers. They take care to ensure you are unable to follow them before disappearing.
Confused, impressed or afraid... you're not sure which; Skaven features are so hard to read. Either way, your ruse works: the Skaven eventually offer you tribute before quickly departing.
The more you talk, the less the Skaven seem to buy your story. Eventually they tire of listening and attack you. In the ensuing struggle, you escape with your life, but barely.
Would the Skaven really leave evidence of their researches just lying around? You think not; obviously, this is an ambush, so you leave without further ado.
Your experts are impressed by the Skaven's grasp of technology. This is ground-breaking stuff, revealing new manufacturing methods that could be used to your advantage.
You order your experts glean whatever they can from it. However, their time is wasted - nothing worthwhile is discovered and your citizens are disgusted that you brought such evil into their midst.
Time spent searching the area reveals no ratmen lying in wait to surprise you. You collect the discarded machinery and find a rival Skaven clan eager to make a deal.
As no ambush presents itself, you take the machinery to rival Skaven who are known to pay for any advantage over their nemeses. However, they refuse, as it was abandoned for good reason...
Whatever these Skaven intended, their feeble science is of little interest. The reclaimed materials are put to good use by your own artisans. There are no obvious ill effects... for now.
You have the machines melted down for your own purposes. However, the metals are laced with disease that quickly kills your artisans and spreads through your population.
The fungi are tempting, but could easily be poisonous - regardless of any corruption that the Dark Prince may have instilled within.
After inhaling the fungus your retainers are full of vitality but a strange glint in their eyes reveals the cost of this new found strength. Time to enlist some new followers, methinks!
It's probably best not to take any chances. You flatten the patch, removing the temptation of Chaos from the path of any and all who pass by.
As your retainers stamp the patch flat the air becomes thick with spores. It isn't long before the taint of Chaos becomes apparent in their eyes and on their skin!

There's more to be found here than a few poxy mushrooms! You command your retainers to ignore it and continue searching the area. At last, they find a stash of gold hidden in the bole of a rotten tree.
You command your retainers to ignore the fungi and search the area. They find nothing. Perhaps they're useless or maybe this is the beginning of Chaos' fell taint?
Backing away slowly you make it out of the caverns without alerting the spiders to your presence - a lucky escape!
After a hard-fought battle you slay all of the spiders and retrieve the item from their web. Whatever it is, it better be worth it!
You fight bravely but the spiders soon overwhelm you. After taking a wound in the arm you flee the caverns, barely making it to safety.
You cut through the cobwebs, avoiding the spiders and quickly retrieve the item you spotted glinting behind them.
The second your blade touches the web, hundreds of smaller spiders swarm from the darkness, engulfing you and your party. All is lost!
You ignore the spiders and take a different path into the caverns. Deep beneath the earth you find a long forgotten horde of treasure.
You ignore the spiders and take a different path into the caverns. Unfortunately, the search soon proves fruitless.
This place has known the touch of the gods - and maybe not the patrons of your own race! it would be wise to leave, at once!
You retrieve the sword and make a hasty escape - who knows what tricks and traps may have been left for even the wariest treasure hunter?
The second you touch the blade a cloud of purple smoke engulfs you. You stumble and bump into the walls - clearly, your mind is no longer your own...
A golden tribute to the gods sees the purple glow dissipate; gradually, the ancient sword dulls. On closer inspection it is a fine weapon worthy of a fine warrior!
These passages were not dug for nought; a thorough search unearths treasures beyond counting! Your retainers gather it swiftly, yet carefully, in case of traps.
A rumbling begins, gradually getting louder. Otherworldly, maniacal laughter emanates from... somewhere close. This place is cursed! Only fools would venture further!
Books are worthless, especially when your business is the accumulation of wealth or the annihilation of your opposition. Leave them behind.
The translator gives back the book, his hands shaking. He informs you that it is a tome of great import, the contents of which will change the way we view the world forever.
The translator hands back the book, glancing at the weapons slung at your belt before speaking. Cautiously, he informs you that the Tome is entirely without value!
The translator informs you that the book is an ancient treatise on warfare, full of forgotten tactics. With the appropriate level of study, it could tip the scales in your favour.

The translator says that it is in fact an ancient cookbook written by a certain 'Horston Burgerstal'. It contains a number of bizarre culinary concoctions, many of which look like they might be poisonous!
Following a hasty and not-very-thorough inspection, the local book dealer says he is more than happy to take the volumes off your hands. Perhaps he is a little too happy...
The local book dealer stops short of actually laughing in your face and wastes little time informing you that the books have no value... other than to a budding poisoner!
It is well known that the Underworld Sea is home to vicious monsters who will easily kill and eat your party if disturbed. Better to live to see another day...
A Kraken rises from the depths and attacks your party! After a hard-fought battle you are able to subdue the beast, but start to wonder if this treasure hunting malarkey is really worth the effort!
A Kraken rises from the waters and attacks your party! After a lengthy fight you are badly wounded and limp back to the surface. You conclude that there must be easier ways to swell your coffers!
On a pedestal in the centre of a still lake sits an item of great magical power. Discovering that the lake is shallow, you wade out and collect the object.
As you delve deeper into the caverns you become helplessly lost, and members of your party begin to panic. Clearly, it will be some time before you see the sun again...
A small row boat allows you to search the shallows. As it does so, a gleam of gold catches your eye. You haul the chest to the surface and treasure spills into the boat.
A small row boat allows you to search the shallows. On hearing the distant roar of a Kraken, your retainers all decide to turn tail and head for the entrance. Spineless cretins, all!
Sacred ground should never be disturbed. You are wise to leave the dead to their breathless, eternal sleep and move on.
It takes several retainers to shift the lid of the sarcophagus. As it slides away, you are immediately rewarded for your pains; the gleam of gold from within is almost blinding.
It isn't easy to open the sarcophagus but when the lid finally moves a terrible stench of decay rises; you've just met the tomb's owner, in all his funereal glory!
As you wipe the dirt from the artefact it glows with an eerie light; you feel a low pulse coursing through it and into your body.
You look around for a clue. Just as you are about to give up, an inscription on the wall reveals the location of a treasure vault, deep beneath the tomb.
You look around for a clue, feeling that the riches are surely close by. After an hour of fruitless searching, however, it becomes clear there is nothing here to be found.
So what if their homes have been destroyed? At least they still have their lives! You decide their plight isn't your problem and walk away.
You free the survivors from the rubble. Grateful for your kindness, they swear a vow to serve you until their dying days. You suppose there may one day be a need for them.
You free the survivors from the rubble. Grateful for your kindness, they swear a vow to serve you until their dying days. You suppose there may one day be a need for them.
Your retainers get to work, moving much of the rubble, but by the time you get to the bodies it is already too late.
The survivors say they will lead you to a cache of supplies in return for saving their lives. After you free them, they make good on their promise.
Amazed by your callousness, the survivors let out a string of curses as you walk away. They will all die, but it is too late to reverse the effects of their magical mischief.
Ignoring the cries for help you continue your search and find a small cache of gemstones in a collapsed building nearby. Truly, a serendipitous event!
Ignoring the cries for help you continue your search, but there is nothing of value. Time to leave...
Trapped, you resign yourself to a long wait - it is some time before a retainer triggers the same mechanism and releases you.
The mechanism is actually pretty simple and you easily manage to open the doors. As they slide open a secret panel is revealed, containing Dwarfen riches.
Tinkering with the mechanism causes the doors to fly open, but the vault collapses around you. You get out before you're buried alive, but it was a very narrow escape.

Some rudimentary investigation reveals a small trapdoor, hidden beneath some barrels, in the corner of the room. The passageway beneath leads back to the vault; you emerge from another direction, to the surprise of your retainers.

In the attempt to escape you accidentally set off a second trap. A powder keg explodes, blowing the doors open and injuring you in the process and illustrating why you should always take a retainer with you...
The runes explain how to open the door using the complicated mechanism. They also reveal how to construct said mechanism and others like it; Dwarfish secrets? Not for long!
You quickly remember that you have no idea how to read the runes before you, so escape by your own means seems unlikely. Your only option is to sit and wait for rescue.
You stand to gain nothing from engaging the Undead, except perhaps joining them somewhat swifter than planned!
Upon closer inspection you discover they are merely corpses propped up on sticks, intended to protect something. Investigation of the ruins reveals a small hoard of ritual currency hidden within.
Closer inspection reveals the bodies are merely corpses propped up on sticks. You pull them down and give them a decent burial.
You order your troops to attack from range. With impressive precision the Undead are taken down in one volley. This remarkable feat cheers the troops and improves their leadership.
Repeated volleys fail to fell the Unliving enemy. Your troops waste far too much ammunition on a seemingly simple task.
It seems that whatever the Undead are guarding has already been looted - the land around the building has been picked clean.
Whilst you search elsewhere, rumours of the Undead presence spreads. Your people are outraged that you would place plunder above their safety.
Your exploits on the high seas have heralded benign weather, allowing for greater movement in these regions.
Your exploits on the high seas have heralded benign weather, allowing for greater movement in these regions.
Your exploits on the high seas have heralded benign weather, allowing for greater movement in these regions.
Your exploration of the high seas has borne fruit: a bounty of maps to uncharted realms, revealing more of the world.
Your exploration of the high seas has borne fruit: a bounty of maps to uncharted realms, revealing more of the world.
Your exploration of the high seas has borne fruit: a bounty of maps to uncharted realms, revealing more of the world.
During your adventures on the high seas you procured a bounty of rations to stave off attrition and ill-health.
During your adventures on the high seas you procured a bounty of rations to stave off attrition and ill health.
During your adventures on the high seas you procured a bounty of rations to stave off attrition and ill-health.
During your dalliances on the high seas you came across stranded crew, willing to join you in exchange for food and rescue.
During your dalliances on the high seas you came across stranded crew, willing to join you in exchange for food and rescue.
During your dalliances on the high seas you came across stranded crew, willing to join you in exchange for food and rescue.
Your exploits on the high seas has led to the salvage of arcane imbued blades, enhancing your army’s combat skills.
Your exploits on the high seas has led to the salvage of arcane-imbued blades, enhancing your army’s combat skills.
Your exploits on the high seas has led to the salvage of arcane imbued blades, enhancing your army’s combat skills.
During your adventure on the high seas you salvaged heavy armour and an arsenal of weapons.
During your adventure on the high seas you salvaged heavy armour and an arsenal of weapons.
During your adventure on the high seas you salvaged heavy armour and an arsenal of weapons.
Your escapades on the high seas have lumbered your army with a curse… losing their sanity in a blood-induced frenzy!
Your escapades on the high seas have lumbered your army with a curse… losing their sanity in a blood-induced frenzy!
Your escapades on the high seas have lumbered your army with a curse… losing their sanity in a blood-induced frenzy!
Your exploration of the high seas has led to blessings from the Lord of the Deeps – your troops will be protected from harm while they have the Elven God’s favour.
Your exploration of the high seas has led to blessings from the Lord of the Deeps – your troops will be protected from harm while they have the Elven God’s favour.
Your exploration of the high seas has led to blessings from the Lord of the Deeps – your troops will be protected from harm while they have the Elven god’s favour.
Your encounter on the high seas is not one the crew or troops will readily talk about, yet they have gained regenerative abilities since the event…
Your encounter on the high seas is not one the crew or troops will readily talk about, yet they have gained regenerative abilities since the event…
Your encounter on the high seas is not one the crew or troops will readily talk about, yet they have gained regenerative abilities since the event…

A new training regimen for your Heroes teaches them to veil their intent beneath a sheen of civility. After all, a killer with the manners of a rabbit is the most dangerous kind. The chances of successful Hero actions have now improved.
The example you set is inspirational. The Heroes under your command are proud to carry out your will, and do so eagerly. The cost for all Hero actions has fallen.

In a drive to improve combat stamina across your armed forces, the High Quartermaster has been experimenting with new ration combinations. His latest concoction is a bowel-addling patty of horse flesh, pickled fish and Forest Spider spinnerets, served between toasted discs of sweetened bread. They haven't a clue what they're eating but the troops can't get enough. Army replenishment is up, but due to frequent toilet stops, movement range is down.

A conclave of your generals has struck upon the notion of pressing popular musicians into military service. This has come as a shock to the performers in question, but has proved an instant hit with the troops and they’re marching harder than ever before. Army movement range has increased!

Through a network of informants, this Hero has uncovered an assassination plot against you by a high-ranking traitor. Rather than spook the fiend, the Hero let the conspiracy play out, identifying all collaborators in the process, and leapt before the blade as it was thrust. This character is now wounded, but has gained great experience from their actions.
Your Heroes spend every spare moment they have honing their skills, and it shows. This character now has increased their experience.
Your traders have excelled themselves! An over-abundance of quality building materials has appeared on the market, reducing construction costs.

The ferocious foreman of your logging operation has been applying the whip with unseemly zeal. Workers are vacating the camps en masse and timber production is dwindling, driving up the construction costs.
Your buildings have taken critical damage and cannot perform their function. Deploy the repair crews!

The cheap, brittle mortar in your production centres is showing its age. Repair crews have been dispatched but the remedial work is disruptive, and income from your buildings has suffered as a result.

A thaumaturgist in one of your provinces has been tasked with squeezing greater profit from industrial processes. Lost in thought one day while inspecting a smelting plant, he slipped and plunged into the roiling slag. His death was not in vain however, as the smelters discovered that the introduction of osseous matter worked to strengthen the metal, raising its value; profits are up factionwide!
The inhabitants of your empire tire of the constant threat of war on their doorstep. Due to the uncertainty conflict brings, growth has taken a sudden nosedive.
A shrewd programme of stockpiling across your provinces has literally borne fruit, and food-stores are bountifully abundant. The population is in rude health, and growth is on the rise.

A charismatic soothsayer has impassioned the locals in this province with his doctrine of vigorous procreation. While the population is sharply rising, an exhausted workforce is a not a productive one.
This army has undertaken a rigorous new training regime focused on frontline combat, yielding excellent results. All units now have improved melee attack capabilities.
You have instituted defensive training for this army's troops, teaching them to better anticipate incoming blows. All units now have improved melee defence capabilities.

As the Great Vortex vacillates on its axis, the Winds of Magic fluctuate distressingly, eliciting wild-eyed portents of doom from hedge-wizards throughout your empire. The troops are cowed by these omens and leadership has decreased factionwide.
Your forces are benefitting from a protracted period of good weather; rations are plentiful and there's a spring in the troops' stride. As a result, army leadership has increased factionwide!
A network of seditious ne'er-do-wells sows discord in your provinces and control is falling. Seek methods to remedy this before it erupts into a full-blown rebellion!
Conflict in a nearby region has driven the inhabitants into your territory. This has greatly increased local tensions, but represents a rich source of cheap manpower for their armies.

A ribald rhymer of raucous repute has arrived in your lands. As you tour the settlements his vulgar verse spreads like the Galloping Scumpox, sowing boundless cheer in the locals; control has now risen in response.

New targeting techniques have been introduced to your armies' training regimens, teaching the troops to focus on the enemy's weak points. Damage from missile weapons has increased factionwide as a result.

A recent clutch of reports regarding ill-discipline in the lower ranks is cause for concern. Clearly, clods are being hired - this has to stop! Recruitment costs have risen accordingly, but new recruits begin two ranks higher.

A caprice of nature or something more sinister? Either way, this unusually long spell of bitter weather is taking its toll on your armed forces. Replenishment is down, but the appeal of guaranteed rations means new recruits are clamouring to join up, driving down recruitment costs.

Seeking the gift of regeneration, an imprudent cabal of young magic-users has been dabbling in Ogre gastromancy. But disaster strikes, as they inadvertently summon the Great Maw itself! Smacking its lips with delight at the banquet laid out before it, the Maw devours the hapless sorcerers where they stand and disappears with a satisfied belch. This arcane upheaval has sapped the Winds of Magic factionwide!

A microscopic fissure has opened between the material world and the Realm of Chaos. It is a fleeting event, quite beneath the notice of even the gods, but potent enough to invigorate the Winds of Magic power reserve.

The Great Warding teeters on its axis and weakens for a moment. Before it recovers, the Winds of Magic burst forth in a  tumultuous gyre around your army, greatly boosting their power reserve but increasing the likelihood of miscasts.
A rising assassin with an already impressive blood-tally to his name has sworn fealty to you and is now available for use. Send him forth in Khaine's bloody name!

When a slave steps on your foot, how should you respond? With incandescent rage perhaps, consuming them and several others in a coruscating conflagration? This young Dark One did just that, to your resounding approval, and is now available for use.

A bitter blood-feud between two lieutenants in this army - one feared and respected, the other universally loathed - has been swiftly dealt with. Perhaps too swiftly, for in his rage the wrong Elf was slain. As a result, the army's leadership has fallen and recruitment costs have risen too.

A highborn Lord of Ulthuan has been captured along with his honour-guard. Naturally, they are being paraded around this province in chains before their inevitable – and exquisitely slow – public execution. The local inhabitants are ecstatic at this delicious turn of events, resulting in local improvements to control and army leadership.

Uncommonly clement weather has driven the gargantuan denizens of the seas further north, resulting in an easy season of raiding and pillaging across the ocean for the reavers. Now, the streets of Karond Kar throng with fresh slaves, ripe and ready to be distributed around Naggaroth. Due to this influx of fresh labour, building costs have decreased factionwide.

A Dreadlord of Hag Graef has formed a compact with a Lord of Chaos! Even as he enjoys the dark pleasures his deal has bought, the twisted influence of the Dark Gods insinuates itself across your holdings. As a result, Chaos corruption has risen factionwide.

A Cold One breeder, reputed for his voracious pit-fighting animals, has exploited his trade-contacts to acquire certain rare fungi used by the Night Goblins. Thus dosed, his enraged creations are unstoppable against regular stock. In fact the compound is so effective than none will now bet against the beasts; there's just no sport in it! The pit-owners refuse to field them and sales have fallen off a cliff, so the breeder has offered you his surfeit of reeking 'shrooms. The answer, quite obviously, is "Yes!" Duly dosed, his Cold One units now have enhanced melee attack capabilities factionwide.

A building in one of your settlements has suffered catastrophic damage! Irksomely, but fairly inconsequentially, it has also collapsed on a great congregation of slaves. Naturally, it must be repaired before it can function again, and the slave population in this province has declined.

Crone Hellebron has ordered Death Night be extended by two further nights this year. The streets of Har Ganeth are awash with blood and viscera as its inhabitants release their pent-up, year-long furies in a breathtaking orgy of bloodletting. As a result, Witch Elf recruitment costs have fallen, and their starting experience level has increased.

The administrator of this province has been slain in the most grisly and ingenious fashion. While the artful method of his demise is loudly applauded by his peers, they soon descend into infighting and murderous quarrels in a bid to outdo the assassin and claim the office for themselves. The population, left unchecked, soon follows suit. Now, growth in this province is falling!

A sharp-tongued troubadour is touring your lands, reminding his audiences of how Bel Shanaar succeeded Aenarion to become the second Phoenix Lord, denying the Witch King his birthright. Your subjects' hatred is whetted anew, their fury toward the Asur reawakened in earnest. Factionwide, your warriors now have improved leadership and melee attack when fighting against the High Elves.

As the slave population has now dropped to barely-sustainable levels, local administrators have outlawed the inhabitants from slaying them at whim. The violent public outcry can be heard clear to the city limits. Control has fallen as a result!

A fashion for devising new and more exquisite forms of torture has developed among the lower ranks, and they are practicing it every chance that they get! A tongue under duress may reveal many secrets, after all. As one might expect, the income from raiding and sacking has increased factionwide.

Faced with yet more bland rations, this army has turned to the dark practice of cannibalism... with the hearty blessing of its catering corps, of course. Now, once a battle has been won, limbs of the slain are being enthusiastically collected, salted and cured for the long road ahead, with the troops thriving on these most morbid of provisions. Replenishment rate and army movement range have increased as a result.

Following successful raids on key targets in enemy lands, a number of enemy intellectuals have been 'acquired'. With a little persuasion, their skills and experience have been harnessed - they have been put to work improving the level of technology available to you in order that he might score further victories over the hated foe and bring about rightful Druchii supremacy. Just as you intended, the rate of research has increased factionwide, and requiring very little effort from anyone other than the slaves, whose lot it is to suffer and die!

The rival salvagers you spotted turned out to be a freebooting horde of Undead pirates. As you approached the putrid remains, they turned their guns and cannons on you. After dispatching them in the ensuing sea battle, you looted their galleon’s coffers which had recently been filled with trinkets and valuables extracted from the dead beast’s belly.

The rival salvagers you spotted turned out to be a freebooting horde of Undead pirates. As you approached the putrid remains, they turned their guns and cannons on you. After dispatching them in the ensuing sea battle, you looted their galleon’s coffers which had recently been filled with trinkets and valuables extracted from the dead beast’s belly.

The rival salvagers you spotted turned out to be a freebooting horde of Undead pirates. As you approached the putrid remains, they turned their guns and cannons on you. After dispatching them in the ensuing sea battle, you looted their galleon’s coffers which had recently been filled with trinkets and valuables extracted from the dead beast’s belly.

Before you could reach the sea monster’s corpse you were suddenly accosted by a horde of Undead pirates also staking a claim to the potentially valuable remains. After dispatching them in the ensuing sea battle, you looted their galleon’s coffers before sailing on to the beast’s remains, where your crew were able to cut open its belly and extract further wealth and treasures.

Before you could reach the sea monster’s corpse you were suddenly accosted by a horde of Undead pirates also staking a claim to the potentially valuable remains. After dispatching them in the ensuing sea battle, you looted their galleon’s coffers before sailing on to the beast’s remains, where your crew were able to cut open its belly and extract further wealth and treasures.

Before you could reach the sea monster’s corpse you were suddenly accosted by a horde of Undead pirates also staking a claim to the potentially valuable remains. After dispatching them in the ensuing sea battle, you looted their galleon’s coffers before sailing on to the beast’s remains, where your crew were able to cut open its belly and extract further wealth and treasures.

A corpse of such a size does not go unnoticed by the brigands of the sea, and sure enough on your way to the monster’s remains you are accosted by a Vampire Admiral’s fleet. After dispatching them in the ensuing sea battle, you looted their galleon before sailing on to the leviathan's remains, where your crew were able to cut open its belly and extract further wealth and treasures.

A corpse of such a size does not go unnoticed by the brigands of the sea, and sure enough on your way to the monster’s remains you are accosted by a Vampire Admiral’s fleet. After dispatching them in the ensuing sea battle, you looted their galleon before sailing on to the leviathan's remains, where your crew were able to cut open its belly and extract further wealth and treasures.

A corpse of such a size does not go unnoticed by the brigands of the sea, and sure enough on your way to the monster’s remains you are accosted by a Vampire Admiral’s fleet. After dispatching them in the ensuing sea battle, you looted their galleon before sailing on to the leviathan's remains, where your crew were able to cut open its belly and extract further wealth and treasures.

Such vast wealth does not go missing out on the open ocean without pirates catching wind of it, and before long a galleon helmed by a particularly belligerent Vampire Admiral appeared in a cloud of broadside guns and hissing black powder weapons, blocking your passage. After defeating the Undead freebooter, you looted their galleon’s coffers before sailing on to claim the salvage from the convoy for yourself.

Such vast wealth does not go missing out on the open ocean without pirates catching wind of it, and before long a galleon helmed by a particularly belligerent Vampire Admiral appeared in a cloud of broadside guns and hissing black powder weapons, blocking your passage. After defeating the Undead freebooter, you looted their galleon’s coffers before sailing on to claim the salvage from the convoy for yourself.

Such vast wealth does not go missing out on the open ocean without pirates catching wind of it, and before long a galleon helmed by a particularly belligerent Vampire Admiral appeared in a cloud of broadside guns and hissing black powder weapons, blocking your passage. After defeating the Undead freebooter, you looted their galleon’s coffers before sailing on to claim the salvage from the convoy for yourself.

While sailing towards the wreckage of the ship from Marienburg, a galleon helmed by a hissing Vampire Admiral appeared in a cloud of broadside guns and cracking black powder weapons, blocking your passage. After defeating the Undead freebooter, you looted their galleon’s coffers before sailing on to claim the salvage from the Marienburg wreck for yourself.

While sailing towards the wreckage of the ship from Marienburg, a galleon helmed by a hissing Vampire Admiral appeared in a cloud of broadside guns and cracking black powder weapons, blocking your passage. After defeating the Undead freebooter, you looted their galleon’s coffers before sailing on to claim the salvage from the Marienburg wreck for yourself.

While sailing towards the wreckage of the ship from Marienburg, a galleon helmed by a hissing Vampire Admiral appeared in a cloud of broadside guns and cracking black powder weapons, blocking your passage. After defeating the Undead freebooter, you looted their galleon’s coffers before sailing on to claim the salvage from the Marienburg wreck for yourself.

As you approached the wreckage, a galleon of Undead pirates appeared in a cloud of broadside guns and hissing black powder weapons, seeking to claim the sunken ship’s treasure for themselves. After defeating the Undead freebooters, you looted their galleon’s coffers before sailing on to claim the salvage from the sunken ship for yourself.

As you approached the wreckage, a galleon of Undead pirates appeared in a cloud of broadside guns and hissing black powder weapons, seeking to claim the sunken ship’s treasure for themselves. After defeating the Undead freebooters, you looted their galleon’s coffers before sailing on to claim the salvage from the sunken ship for yourself.

As you approached the wreckage, a galleon of Undead pirates appeared in a cloud of broadside guns and hissing black powder weapons, seeking to claim the sunken ship’s treasure for themselves. After defeating the Undead freebooters, you looted their galleon’s coffers before sailing on to claim the salvage from the sunken ship for yourself.

Before you can set foot upon the island, you are set upon by a Vampire Admiral who had arrived there just before you and was bolstering his forces with the reanimated corpses of the dead crewmen rotting on the beaches. After defeating the Undead freebooters, you looted the Vampire’s moored galleon before claiming all the salvage on the island for yourself.

Before you can set foot upon the island, you are set upon by a Vampire Admiral who had arrived there just before you and was bolstering his forces with the reanimated corpses of the dead crewmen rotting on the beaches. After defeating the Undead freebooters, you looted the Vampire’s moored galleon before claiming all the salvage on the island for yourself.

Before you can set foot upon the island, you are set upon by a Vampire Admiral who had arrived there just before you and was bolstering his forces with the reanimated corpses of the dead crewmen rotting on the beaches. After defeating the Undead freebooters, you looted the Vampire’s moored galleon before claiming all the salvage on the island for yourself.

Compelled by the eerie songs carried on the sea breeze, you ordered your crew to disembark onto the mysterious islet. Before you could start searching for treasures, however, you are set upon by some Vampire pirates who seemed to have appeared out of nowhere. The songs of the cursed Syreens were obviously a trap! After defeating the Undead freebooters controlling them, you looted the Vampire’s moored galleon before claiming all the salvage on the island for yourself.

Compelled by the eerie songs carried on the sea breeze, you ordered your crew to disembark onto the mysterious islet. Before you could start searching for treasures, however, you are set upon by some Vampire pirates who seemed to have appeared out of nowhere. The songs of the cursed Syreens were obviously a trap! After defeating the Undead freebooters controlling them, you looted the Vampire’s moored galleon before claiming all the salvage on the island for yourself.

Compelled by the eerie songs carried on the sea breeze, you ordered your crew to disembark onto the mysterious islet. Before you could start searching for treasures, however, you are set upon by some Vampire pirates who seemed to have appeared out of nowhere. The songs of the cursed Syreens were obviously a trap! After defeating the Undead freebooters controlling them, you looted the Vampire’s moored galleon before claiming all the salvage on the island for yourself.

Before you can set foot upon the island, you are set upon by a Vampire Admiral who had arrived there just before you and was bolstering his forces with the reanimated corpses of the shipwrecked dead rotting amongst the rocks. After defeating the Undead freebooters, you looted the Vampire’s moored galleon before claiming all the salvage on the island for yourself.

Before you can set foot upon the island, you are set upon by a Vampire Admiral who had arrived there just before you and was bolstering his forces with the reanimated corpses of the shipwrecked dead rotting amongst the rocks. After defeating the Undead freebooters, you looted the Vampire’s moored galleon before claiming all the salvage on the island for yourself.

Before you can set foot upon the island, you are set upon by a Vampire Admiral who had arrived there just before you and was bolstering his forces with the reanimated corpses of the shipwrecked dead rotting amongst the rocks. After defeating the Undead freebooters, you looted the Vampire’s moored galleon before claiming all the salvage on the island for yourself.

The pirate cove contained great wealth in the form of treasures and items stolen from across the four corners, but getting to it was no easy feat. When the Vampire Admiral at the helm of the black ship saw you approach, he immediately readied his horde of crewmen and darkling creatures for battle. After defeating the Undead freebooters, you ransacked their ship as well as the hidden cave to make for a plentiful hoard!

The pirate cove contained great wealth in the form of treasures and items stolen from across the four corners, but getting to it was no easy feat. When the Vampire Admiral at the helm of the black ship saw you approach, he immediately readied his horde of crewmen and darkling creatures for battle. After defeating the Undead freebooters, you ransacked their ship as well as the hidden cave to make for a plentiful hoard!

The pirate cove contained great wealth in the form of treasures and items stolen from across the four corners, but getting to it was no easy feat. When the Vampire Admiral at the helm of the black ship saw you approach, he immediately readied his horde of crewmen and darkling creatures for battle. After defeating the Undead freebooters, you ransacked their ship as well as the hidden cave to make for a plentiful hoard!
A highborn warrior of the Asur has arrived at court and pledged his service to you in whatever capacity you see fit. He respectfully awaits your orders.

A powerful Mage - one schooled in the ancient ways first developed by the mighty Caledor Dragontamer - has pledged his allegiance to you. Elves of such distinction, who have immersed themselves completely in the study of High Magic, should be retained and deployed in your service, to the detriment of his enemies!

A sheaf of Elven architectural manuscripts dating from the reign of Caradryel have been discovered by your spies in the Old World. They detail techniques long forgotten, espousing principles so old as to be new again. As a result, building costs have decreased factionwide.

The earth is more ancient than the Elven race, and seems to favour your primacy. Perhaps it divines the gravity of the mission, and in turn reduces its own, for their troops find marching is easier and less tiring than was previously the case. Campaign movement ranges have increased factionwide as a result.

All eyes turn anxiously to the Isle of the Dead, as the Great Vortex seems to shimmer and slow on its axis. There are fell whispers on the breeze, and all seem troubled in ways they cannot define. As a result, insidious, creeping Chaos corruption has increased factionwide.
A building's structure has become unsound, and those within have been evacuated. In order to restore its function, it must be repaired soon.

The people of this province are deeply troubled. Rumours abound of some unnamed plot hatched in Naggaroth that will come to imminent fruition and, while you suspect that this is some insidious form of propaganda, it is beginning to affect their everyday lives. Growth has fallen as a result.

One of this army's lieutenants has attempted to curry favour with his captain using the largesse of his family's estate. The offer turned sour when the captain, looking more deeply into his subordinate's background, discovered his house to be a distant ally of Morathi. Publicly denouncing the Lieutenant - who has since left the service - should have worked, but the army's reputation has been harmed beyond immediate repair. Army leadership has fallen, and recruitment costs have risen as a result of this shame.

An exquisitely penned history of the Phoenix Lord Bel Shanaar has become widely popular. This artful blending of poetry and prose has caught the imagination of the people and has awakened within them a fresh hatred for Malekith and the foul betrayals of the Druchii. As a result, leadership capabilities when facing Dark Elves have risen factionwide.

This province has declared a month of celebration in honour of the Everqueen. With poignant theatre, public dances, contests of wit, great feasts and a host of other cultural events. Hearts are lightened and the cares of the world fall way, if only briefly – for now, control and army leadership have risen in this province.

In a expression of deep and abiding respect for their winged mounts, a detachment of Phoenix Guard has journeyed to the Shrine of Asuryan, and performed a ritual to Aqshy, the Wind of Fire. Thus invigorated, Aqshy blows hard and fierce, in turn suffusing the Flamespyre Phoenixes with a newfound vitality. Even the Frostheart Phoenixes are impressed with this gift to their younger brethren. As a result, Phoenix recruitment costs have fallen factionwide.

A popular troupe of actors has been touring this province, but their performances seem darker and more perverse with each fresh act. Do they dare spread the twisted influence of – whisper it – the Cult of Pleasure? The common gossip suggests as much, yet the authorities do nothing to intervene! As you might expect, control in this province has decreased as a result.

A High Sister of Avelorn has compiled much practical wisdom and advanced missile techniques, such as trajectory calculus, into a manual of sorts. This splendid new tome has been circulated to your armies in order to enhance their training regimes; the experience of missile unit recruits has risen as a result.

A mage wielding the Lore of Life has agreed to travel with this army, but on condition that he does not have step foot near a battlefield. He reserves his art for the aftermath and, while prevention is always better than cure, it's hard to argue with his results. Following his recruitment, this force now has an enhanced replenishment rate.

Many years ago an old and respected seer disappeared into the Dragon Spine Mountains. Trackers were sent and a rescue expedition assembled, but to no avail. He was given up for lost... until now. His recent reappearance at  Caledor has prompted great rejoicing, and it transpires he spent his time in deep communion with an ancient Star Dragon who, sensing a kindred spirit, taught him much about the world's hidden Warp. As a result, your research rate has increased factionwide.

Your silver-tongued traders are outdoing themselves; they could sell a beard to a Dawi and make it seem a luxury! Now, the holds of your trade-ships are packed to the gunwhales with exotic goods and levies are at an all-time high. As a result of this mercantile excellence, trade income has increased factionwide.

The raging Sea-God, Stromfels, has gone missing, perhaps blown too far south by the arcane tempest that is consuming the world. With his absence, the Great Ocean is becalmed. The denizens of this world sense an opportunity - it is now no longer for the Elves to dominate the seas alone. Other powers seek to ply the oceans, hunt for treasures and expand their empires abroad. However, they must not mistake a calm sea for a safe one - there are still countless dangers lurking in the deeps!

Some dare defy us - we shall sour relations between {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}. In the long-term this will be far more destructive than a direct strike.

By planting some key pieces of evidence we can make it look as though {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} has been secretly worshipping a god that {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} finds particularly offensive. They will deny, and therefore look guilty.

While our ambassadors will not outright lie, they can target certain truths that may sound far worse out of context. And so we whisper in the ear of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} that {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} is not to be trusted.

Our trade routes are reliable and well-patrolled, if others want to use them they must pay. However, if we levy an additional tithe on {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and claim it is not our tax but one demanded by {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}, then relations will surely sour.

A Caravan of precious baubles important to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} has gone missing. Our agents may have been responsible, but placing a few corpses belonging to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} should switch the blame to them.

A generous gift has been received by {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} from {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}. Unbeknownst to both, the shipment was intercepted en route, the gifts replaced by inferior copies in much lower quantities than promised.

{{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} has been specifically forbidden to act this way due to a pact signed by {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}. They have done no such thing of course, but our agents will tell the signee otherwise.

We offer our services as a neutral party to negotiate a trade agreement between {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}. While our factors smile and encourage, they will be briefing against the interests of both.

A wagon full of high-quality blades and armour has been delivered to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}. It is mere child’s play to insinuate that this gift is from {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} – they will be too stupid and flattered to deny it!

There’s nothing clever or subtle here, simply our agent disguising themselves though mundane and arcane means into a factor of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and giving a large gift of precious things to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}.

Let the races believe the notion that we dwindle but that our reach is still vast, our power to adjudicate and even dictate trade relations remains unchallenged. Granting {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} favourable trade relations will strengthen relations between them, for our gain.

While the younger races frolic and fight we take advantage for our gains. Let us advise {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} to make overtures to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}. If they think it is their own idea, then more’s the better!

Nothing fosters relations than the death of a common foe. So, sending hated corpses to both {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}, and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}, each with missives attached to the bodies claiming credit, should fool these two factions into strengthening their bonds.

Our embassies are often thought of as neutral ground to even the most hated of foes. Nothing could be further from the truth, obviously, but we control the environment and manipulate everything from ambience to the subject of conversation, ensuring that {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} are more predisposed to each other.

Diverting an enemy into the ambush range of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} is the first part of the ploy; letting them keep the gold we planted on the convoy will lead them to a more favourable relationship with {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}, whose sigil is stamped into the hoard.

We have many relics in our archives, trinkets to us but sacred for others. A gift given to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}, will make them more receptive to our scheme of including {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} in the next phase.

One of your agents, posing as a Druchii, stirs the cauldron of hate. Fostering resentment between {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} with lies both white… and dark.

While frowned upon in Ulthuan, hiring a Khainite Assassin is common practice in Naggaroth, so let us put a contract on {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}; failure is irrelevant as long as {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} is implicated.

Not all brave Asur are on the battlefields, some commit to a covert life hidden in Druchii society for the good of Ulthuan. This one has taken the role of paramour and can influence through bed sport, suggesting to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} that {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} is not an ally but a foe.

Manipulate a Dreadlord to believe that {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} is working hand-in-gauntlet with {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} at court, thus forcing them apart.

The Druchii are keen users of poison, so we shall spike the food of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}. Not to kill, but to give a nasty ache. When suspicion falls upon the cook, let us ensure they are in {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}’s thrall.

To flatter and bribe is to ensure favour… delivering a gift of slaves to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} is regrettable for the captives, but if we frame this as {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}’s generosity it will strengthen the bond between these two factions, and be advantageous for us.

Send {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} a corpse - but not one of our own. We shall send them back one of their own sleeper agents - not that they will know why they were killed. And on this corpse a message stressing the {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}’s predisposition to the Druchii.

There are always enemies and annoyances for kings, queens and Dreadlords to overcome. Paying a contract to rid them of such a foe will leave {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} predisposed to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}, especially if we let it be known they hired the assassin.

Who knows more about the intrigues and secrets within the dread citadels? The advisors? The paramours? It is the torturers, of course, for they get the unvarnished truth. And if a certain torturer is in our employ they can report to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and encourage stronger ties with {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} using what they learnt during recent ‘extractions’.

Sending {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} a list of their enemies and allies might be viewed with a certain suspicion, but if we make sure that {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} is in the allies’ column and add an enemy’s finger for verisimilitude, it might be believed.

Wagons full of imperial goods frequently depart to foreign lands. A particularly large convoy disappeared, however. An investigation found the merchants and guards tied to trees and all the wagons plundered. The foreign lord denies any responsibility, but even a child knows that he is to blame for not keeping the roads clear.

A noble has managed to get himself in an embarrassing position. While a foreign dignitary was visiting, rumours started circulating that the noble was ridiculing the foreign delegation behind their backs and even hired a few jesters to give a private performance to mock them. Of course the noble denied it, but a few days later, a letter addressed to his wife surfaced, in which he expressed his disdain for the foreign dignitary. The delegation departed at once and spread the stories of their mistreatment back home.

The wife of a local baron went missing without a trace. Weeks pass and searches return nothing. At the next full moon however, she is found dead and mutilated, hanging above the city gate. A letter was stuffed into her throat, with another faction expressing their hatred for the baron and claiming responsibility.
An influential Lord found a small box on the doorstep of his castle. Upon opening it, he discovered an exquisite jewel, along with a note from an unexpected foreign admirer...

An exotic Caravan appears in mankind's realm, claiming to be from a foreign kingdom. Their goods are of high quality and their prices low. Intrigued by the opportunities of trade, merchants soon flock to the foreign territory in the hopes of securing a good deal.

Seemingly random lords received an invitation of a tournament hosted near Nuln. Upon arrival, they discovered that the tournament grounds have been set up and a foreign delegation was already present. But the foreigners claim they received a similar invitation, and no-one knows who is the host, nor how the tournament grounds were erected. A crate with a massive golden trophy is soon discovered. Both sides agree to compete honourably, with the winning faction receiving the trophy. After the festivities end, both sides agree they had a great time together and the tournament should become an annual event.

While they can be blunt, the Asur tend to veil insults through the arts. In the name of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}, commission a particularly stinging song about {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}. Don’t forget a catchy chorus to ensure it travels beyond court.

Have our servants talk to the serfs of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}, let them spread vicious gossip about the plans of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}. Such talk shall quickly work its way up to the Nobles.

{{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} has the manners of a drunk Dwarf! Such a lack of eloquence does not go unnoticed. Of course, this may have been exacerbated by potion poured into their wine. Nevertheless, it reflects badly on the host, {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}.

The simplest ploys are often the most effective. Through the chatter of court, let it be known that {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} have been overheard defaming Finubar, wondering if he is up to the duties that come with the crown.

There is a constant fear that anyone in Ulthuan could be one of the Witch King’s agents in deep cover. It is almost too easy to lay a whispered suggestion that the life partner of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} takes orders from Naggarond. Just ensure they know the rumour came from {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}.

To accuse {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} of worshipping the gods of the underworld is a serious charge. Although not technically illegal, it is frowned upon, and the loss of standing in the Phoenix Court will be quick. So, proof is needed, which is why you have installed a statue of Atharti at the accused estate, with a note of appreciation from {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}.

The Cults of Pleasure are insidious. The gossip at court is that {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} attended a party hosted by {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} and the excesses witnessed were scandalous. The talk is untrue, of course, but the more they deny, the faster the rumour spreads.

The most effective way to damage relationships is to insinuate rather than use a Dawi’s bluntness. A half-jape to a prince here, a missive sent to an outer kingdom that doesn’t give the full story there… soon there is suspicion between {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}. As we intended.

A careful discussion here, a subtle word over wine there, a smile that lingers, an eyebrow raised over a jest - all things men and Dwarfs would never pick up on. But for the Asur these are powerful social symbols, signs of alliance between two great houses of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}.

Our kin take great store in words and verse. Send a poet to the estates of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} so that they may sing a verse, commissioned by us, of the great relations between them and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}.

The game of court has winners and losers; the fate of houses can be lost not just by invasion but by their Prince’s performance at court. Lending vocal support to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} at court will enhance their relationship with {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}.

Business at the Phoenix Court rarely happens while the king attends and deals with matters of state. It is when the Princes and Nobles splinter off to the alcoves and form informal sub-committees that things get done and so, over a few cups of wine, the binding of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} can begin.

Finubar’s war council is not an official organisation, more the Phoenix King’s close associates that guide and advise on matters of war. To be invited into the council is a great honour, so engineer {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}’s participation with {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} to improve their relations.

Taking on a ward or squire from another house is a good way of exerting soft power and strengthening lasting bonds between two houses or kingdoms. And so {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} has taken a princeling of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}.

The favour of Finubar will do wonders for any great Elven house. Ensure {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} receives patronage of the Phoenix King. Make it known through courtly gossip that it was fostered by {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}.

The lizard’s inability to tell apart some races - especially the Druchii and Asur - give us an advantage to sour relations. An ambush by our hand on {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} can be easily framed to make {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} look responsible.

Some say it is impossible to deceive the Slann, that the great toads perceive all and the reason they do not stop our plots and mummery is that they believe it is all part of their Great Plan – let us test this notion and set {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} against each other.

A rather brutish technique is to smash some plaques that the Lizardmen hold in high regard. The subtlety comes in selecting which of the reptiles’ sacred plaques to destroy, in turn leading them to conclude that relations between {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} should sour.

A dark deed, one which Isha would not approve even if Ereth Khial does. A potion delivered into a spawning pool will sour the water and stunt Lizardmen growth. This will anger {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}; leave the phial close by, with the imprint of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}.

If we tell the gullible reptiles that an alliance between {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} is part of their Great Plan then they will action it. If they question the provenance of such a claim, then say it was on some ancient scroll or other.

We need a more stable relationship between {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}. A few new hieroglyphs in these ‘ancient’ plaques should be enough of a catalyst.

Send captured Skaven to the Slann as a sacrificial gift to the Old Ones, and their snake god in particular. This should please {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}; imply the sacrifices came from {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} to bolster their relations.

Stolen from the Dark Elves, ancient Cold One eggs can be given to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} as a gift from {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}. They are unlikely to dissuade the notion it was not due to their generosity.

The reptiles’ reliance on prophecy and stellar arrangements make then susceptible for subtle manipulations. Using the Wind of Azyr we can slightly alter the skies and bring the Lizardmen to the conclusion that relations between {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} should be improved.

The easiest way to manipulate the Skaven is to kill an ally or vassal of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and then leave the blade in its back, ensuring the traitorous dagger is etched with the sigil of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}.

Like igniting damp wood, spreading whispers of treachery throughout the Skaven clans is hard at first, especially for an Elf…but once the notion takes hold, once the wood begins to burn, it will spread like wildfire. Hence the rumours that {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} plans to betray {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} will quickly take hold.

The favour – or lack thereof – of the Lords of Decay can easily shatter alliances. By circuitous means, make it known that {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} has fallen afoul of the Council of Thirteen’s wrath due to the machinations of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}.

A more overt attack: strike with Shadow Warriors, kill the allies of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} as they watch and then give {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} a friendly wave before disappearing back into the night. It will not be the dead that they focus on but the wave, which will bring down a cloud of suspicion and paranoia.

What do we have before us but a lump of purest green? Taking Warpstone from Skaven is one of the greatest crimes - killing their kin or allies is a minor annoyance but stealing their Warpstone will get a furious response. And so we shall purloin the green of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}, leaving ‘evidence’ that {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} are the thieves.

The Skaven deal in fell Chaos rock, its presence fortunately extremely rare on Ulthuan. Still, we can acquire it by slaying their kin and then depositing it with {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}}, along with a fraudulent note assigning a generous donation from {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}.

Send a message of greeting and friendship… and a Warptoken bribe to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}. At the same time, send the same message to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}. It’s the simplicity of the strategy that is its strength.

The Skaven hate us as much as we do them, so let us use this to our advantage. One of our brave fallen warriors shall become the bait - delivered to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} full of arrows once belonging to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}.

Manipulating a minor ratmen clan is not hard; through various factors, often in disguise as Druchii, we can have the Skaven as our puppets, sending them as neutral ambassadors: first to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} then to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}. Once in our targets’ presence they will squeak and lavish many platitudes to appease their frail egos.
A rare spawning has produced a warrior of superior physical prowess, who is now available for service. Onwards, in the service of the Great Plan!
A Skink Priest of great skill has arisen from the sacred spawning pools and is now available for service!

A reputed Skink artisan has been dispatched to oversee construction work throughout your provinces. His guidance has highlighted where efficiency is lacking and savings may be made. Building construction costs have now decreased factionwide.

The Geomantic Web pulses erratically for a moment, as if something unearthly had touched it. The Mage-Priests mutter of an ill presence, though they cannot divine the source; however, Chaos corruption has now increased factionwide…

The last Cold One spawning yielded a rare strain, gifted with some notion of your venerable race's plight in their tiny brains. These beasts are so eager to fight for you that they barely need taming, and their urgency means that friendly infantry must trot to keep up. As a result, recruitment costs for Cold One cavalry units have fallen and army movement range has increased factionwide.
