This Oath mission has been completed. Check the [[col:yellow]]Oaths of Iron & Glory[[/col]] panel for details.
Oath missions have been unlocked on the [[col:yellow]]Oaths of Iron & Glory[[/col]] panel!

An Amber Wizard joins our ranks, wielding the Lore of Beasts and enabling the [[col:yellow]]Colleges of Magic[[/col]] actions of the Amber Order.\\n\\nGhur echoes through the veins of those attuned to the Brown Wind of Magic, heard like the cry of a soaring eagle in the midst of flight. Its power grants control over the creatures of the wild, as well as the ability to assume their strength, and hunt down their enemies as prey.

An Amethyst Wizard joins our ranks, wielding the Lore of Death and enabling the [[col:yellow]]Colleges of Magic[[/col]] actions of the Amethyst Order.\\n\\nDrawing power from the residual Shyish surrounding the deceased, a practitioner of the Purple Wind of Magic exists with one foot in the mortal realm and the other in the beyond. Though frequently found communing with spirits and wielding power over the dead, Brethren take care not to stray into the realms of true Necromancy.

A Bright Wizard joins our ranks, wielding the Lore of Fire and enabling the [[col:yellow]]Colleges of Magic[[/col]] actions of the Bright Order.\\n\\nEmbracing the raging flame of Aqshy, the pyromancers that channel the Red Wind of Magic burn a path through the enemies of the Empire. Destructive and violent, the Bright Wizards' fires can be summoned as a searing ball of flame, or wielded as a flaming sword that slashes out at the Emperor's foes.

A Celestial Wizard joins our ranks, wielding the Lore of Heavens and enabling the [[col:yellow]]Colleges of Magic[[/col]] actions of the Celestial Order.\\n\\nEmpowered by the energies of Azyr that surge among the stars, the members of the Celestial Order have honed their masteries of scrying and astromancy. As those wielding the Blue Winds of Magic take to the battlefield, they draw their strength from the upper atmosphere of the mortal world.

A Grey Wizard joins our ranks, wielding the Lore of Shadow and enabling the [[col:yellow]]Colleges of Magic[[/col]] actions of the Grey Order.\\n\\nScorned by some as Trickster Wizards, the self-proclaimed Grey Guardians work beneath the veil of darkness, embracing the energies of Ulgu to cast illusions and sow confusion among their foes. In ventures of conspiracy, subterfuge and scheming, all is facilitated by the Grey Wind of Magic.

A Jade Wizard joins our ranks, wielding the Lore of Life and enabling the [[col:yellow]]Colleges of Magic[[/col]] actions of the Jade Order.\\n\\nCommonly called Druids by those unfamiliar with the Green Wind of Magic, the Wizards of the Green Order channel Ghyran to exert control over the soil itself, allowing flowers to bloom and nature to flourish. With a healing hand, the most skilled practitioners may even mend grievous wounds, restoring soldiers to health.

A Light Wizard joins our ranks, wielding the Lore of Light and enabling the [[col:yellow]]Colleges of Magic[[/col]] actions of the Light Order.\\n\\nWhere darkness lingers, it shall be banished by the hierophants of the Light Order, who wield Hysh to oppose Chaos in all its forms. The serpentine staff of a Light Wizard is often used as a magical sentinel, shielding and protecting the Empire's soldiers just as easily as it might punish the wicked with its radiance.

Where once the Greenskin menace wrought havoc under the Nemesis Crown's sway, peace now reigns in their stead. With the Crown removed from the foul Night Goblin head upon which it sat, the threat to the Empire has been thoroughly extinguished.
Elspeth has long standing alliances with the Cult of Morr. With each new Gardens she errects a new Tower that she might call home.
The enemies of the empire have taken this region as their own and burnt the Gardens and Elspeth's Tower alike to the ground.
Elspeth atop her mighty Carmine Dragon makes haste to return to one of her Black Towers.

When the Cult of Morr establishes new Gardens, Elspeth is given the opportunity to establish new towers in return for her aid in times of need.\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_gardens_of_morr_view_panel}}

The time has come to settle our scores once again! No Dwarf shall rest until all Grudges have been struck from the book – those who relent must prove themselves in kind!\\n\\n[[img:icon_grudges]][[/img]]Settled Grudges will now count towards your [[col:yellow]]Age of Reckoning[[/col]] progress again.

The Dwarfs have been hard at work striking Grudges from the Book – the current lack of Grudges to settle has become a testament to the collective Dawi resolve to right all their wrongs. The final thing to grumble about is what they will they do with themselves once there's nothing left to grumble over!
That was the last of our {{tr:unit_abilities_onscreen_name_wh3_dlc25_army_abilities_spirit_barrage}} Rockets, we'll need to visit the Amethyst Armoury in order to replenish supplies.

Your supplies of {{tr:unit_abilities_onscreen_name_wh3_dlc25_army_abilities_bjuna_bombard}} Mortar Shells have run dry. The Engineers and Amethyst Wizards will need to head back to their workshops before you can make use of this again.

{{tr:unit_abilities_onscreen_name_wh3_dlc25_army_abilities_purple_eclipse}} has blocked out the sun for the last time, at least until our wizards can channel enough Winds of Shyish to create another terrifying feat of engineering.

The new training grounds affords our troops the best possible learning experience, alongside a separate area for safely testing improved designs for standard-issue weaponry.\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_gunnery_school_panel_more_information}}

The Engineers spend their days engrossed in their Schematics devising ways to improve the apparatus, while Imperial troops train and test them on the firing ranges.\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_gunnery_school_panel_more_information}}

The Amethyst College’s benefaction affords us a workshop where equipment is manufactured using closely guarded experimental techniques, under very strict access conditions.\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_gunnery_school_panel_more_information}}

The Academy of Excellence offers the finest in engineering and firearms training for creative minds and soldiers alike.\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_gunnery_school_panel_more_information}}

After an extended period away from the homeland, you have finally returned. Whatever the current state of the Empire, it is now your duty alongside others who remain here to protect our lands.\\n\\nLearn more about Imperial Authority [[url:script_link_campaign_imperial_authority]]here[[/url]].

Some dare defy us - we shall sour relations between {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}. In the long-term this will be far more destructive than a direct strike.

By planting some key pieces of evidence we can make it look as though {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} has been secretly worshipping a god that {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} finds particularly offensive. They will deny, and therefore look guilty.

While our ambassadors will not outright lie, they can target certain truths that may sound far worse out of context. And so we whisper in the ear of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} that {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} is not to be trusted.

Our trade routes are reliable and well-patrolled, if others want to use them they must pay. However, if we levy an additional tithe on {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and claim it is not our tax but one demanded by {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}, then relations will surely sour.

A Caravan of precious baubles important to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} has gone missing. Our agents may have been responsible, but placing a few corpses belonging to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} should switch the blame to them.

A generous gift has been received by {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} from {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}. Unbeknownst to both, the shipment was intercepted en route, the gifts replaced by inferior copies in much lower quantities than promised.

{{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} has been specifically forbidden to act this way due to a pact signed by {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}. They have done no such thing of course, but our agents will tell the signee otherwise.

We offer our services as a neutral party to negotiate a trade agreement between {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}. While our factors smile and encourage, they will be briefing against the interests of both.

A wagon full of high-quality blades and armour has been delivered to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}. It is mere child’s play to insinuate that this gift is from {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} – they will be too stupid and flattered to deny it!

There’s nothing clever or subtle here, simply our agent disguising themselves though mundane and arcane means into a factor of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and giving a large gift of precious things to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}.

Let the races believe the notion that we dwindle but that our reach is still vast, our power to adjudicate and even dictate trade relations remains unchallenged. Granting {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} favourable trade relations will strengthen relations between them, for our gain.

While the younger races frolic and fight we take advantage for our gains. Let us advise {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} to make overtures to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}. If they think it is their own idea, then more’s the better!

Nothing fosters relations than the death of a common foe. So, sending hated corpses to both {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}, and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}, each with missives attached to the bodies claiming credit, should fool these two factions into strengthening their bonds.

Our embassies are often thought of as neutral ground to even the most hated of foes. Nothing could be further from the truth, obviously, but we control the environment and manipulate everything from ambience to the subject of conversation, ensuring that {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} are more predisposed to each other.

Diverting an enemy into the ambush range of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} is the first part of the ploy; letting them keep the gold we planted on the convoy will lead them to a more favourable relationship with {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}, whose sigil is stamped into the hoard.

We have many relics in our archives, trinkets to us but sacred for others. A gift given to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}, will make them more receptive to our scheme of including {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} in the next phase.

Wagons full of imperial goods frequently depart to foreign lands. A particularly large convoy disappeared, however. An investigation found the merchants and guards tied to trees and all the wagons plundered. The foreign lord denies any responsibility, but even a child knows that he is to blame for not keeping the roads clear.

A noble has managed to get himself in an embarrassing position. While a foreign dignitary was visiting, rumours started circulating that the noble was ridiculing the foreign delegation behind their backs and even hired a few jesters to give a private performance to mock them. Of course the noble denied it, but a few days later, a letter addressed to his wife surfaced, in which he expressed his disdain for the foreign dignitary. The delegation departed at once and spread the stories of their mistreatment back home.

The wife of a local baron went missing without a trace. Weeks pass and searches return nothing. At the next full moon however, she is found dead and mutilated, hanging above the city gate. A letter was stuffed into her throat, with another faction expressing their hatred for the baron and claiming responsibility.
An influential Lord found a small box on the doorstep of his castle. Upon opening it, he discovered an exquisite jewel, along with a note from an unexpected foreign admirer...

An exotic Caravan appears in mankind's realm, claiming to be from a foreign kingdom. Their goods are of high quality and their prices low. Intrigued by the opportunities of trade, merchants soon flock to the foreign territory in the hopes of securing a good deal.

Seemingly random lords received an invitation of a tournament hosted near Nuln. Upon arrival, they discovered that the tournament grounds have been set up and a foreign delegation was already present. But the foreigners claim they received a similar invitation, and no-one knows who is the host, nor how the tournament grounds were erected. A crate with a massive golden trophy is soon discovered. Both sides agree to compete honourably, with the winning faction receiving the trophy. After the festivities end, both sides agree they had a great time together and the tournament should become an annual event.

While they can be blunt, the Asur tend to veil insults through the arts. In the name of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}, commission a particularly stinging song about {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}. Don’t forget a catchy chorus to ensure it travels beyond court.

Have our servants talk to the serfs of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}, let them spread vicious gossip about the plans of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}. Such talk shall quickly work its way up to the Nobles.

{{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} has the manners of a drunk Dwarf! Such a lack of eloquence does not go unnoticed. Of course, this may have been exacerbated by potion poured into their wine. Nevertheless, it reflects badly on the host, {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}.

The simplest ploys are often the most effective. Through the chatter of court, let it be known that {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} have been overheard defaming Finubar, wondering if he is up to the duties that come with the crown.

There is a constant fear that anyone in Ulthuan could be one of the Witch King’s agents in deep cover. It is almost too easy to lay a whispered suggestion that the life partner of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} takes orders from Naggarond. Just ensure they know the rumour came from {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}.

To accuse {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} of worshipping the gods of the underworld is a serious charge. Although not technically illegal, it is frowned upon, and the loss of standing in the Phoenix Court will be quick. So, proof is needed, which is why you have installed a statue of Atharti at the accused estate, with a note of appreciation from {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}.

The Cults of Pleasure are insidious. The gossip at court is that {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} attended a party hosted by {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} and the excesses witnessed were scandalous. The talk is untrue, of course, but the more they deny, the faster the rumour spreads.

The most effective way to damage relationships is to insinuate rather than use a Dawi’s bluntness. A half-jape to a prince here, a missive sent to an outer kingdom that doesn’t give the full story there… soon there is suspicion between {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}. As we intended.

A careful discussion here, a subtle word over wine there, a smile that lingers, an eyebrow raised over a jest - all things men and Dwarfs would never pick up on. But for the Asur these are powerful social symbols, signs of alliance between two great houses of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}.

Our kin take great store in words and verse. Send a poet to the estates of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} so that they may sing a verse, commissioned by us, of the great relations between them and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}.

The game of court has winners and losers; the fate of houses can be lost not just by invasion but by their Prince’s performance at court. Lending vocal support to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} at court will enhance their relationship with {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}.

Business at the Phoenix Court rarely happens while the king attends and deals with matters of state. It is when the Princes and Nobles splinter off to the alcoves and form informal sub-committees that things get done and so, over a few cups of wine, the binding of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} can begin.

Finubar’s war council is not an official organisation, more the Phoenix King’s close associates that guide and advise on matters of war. To be invited into the council is a great honour, so engineer {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}’s participation with {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} to improve their relations.

Taking on a ward or squire from another house is a good way of exerting soft power and strengthening lasting bonds between two houses or kingdoms. And so {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} has taken a princeling of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}.

The favour of Finubar will do wonders for any great Elven house. Ensure {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} receives patronage of the Phoenix King. Make it known through courtly gossip that it was fostered by {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}.
Rumours in the wind talk of other Lords searching for the Nemesis Crown, you better find it before someone else does.

The Nemesis Crown has been discovered and now the ancient artefact rests upon a new brow. The malevolent power of the crown possesses its new master, {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}!

The Nemesis Crown has once again disapeared from the world. Rumours have spread that its bearer, {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}, was unable to meet its great and malign expectations and the crown vanished to seek a new bearer. Though this hearsay is impossible to corroborate, the truth of the matter is that the Nemesis Crown is nowhere to be found. The civilisations of the world wait with bated breath, hoping that its evil does not return in their lifetimes.

The Nemesis Crown has once again disapeared from the world. Rumours have spread that its bearer was unable to meet its great and malign expectations and the crown vanished to seek a new bearer. Though this hearsay is impossible to corroborate, the truth of the matter is that the Nemesis Crown is nowhere to be found. The civilisations of the world wait with bated breath, hoping that its evil does not return in their lifetimes.

Though the bearer of the Nemesis Crown, {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}, lies slain on the field of battle, so too does the mighty force that fought to claim it. For now, its dark power remains lost to all, awaiting the next fool unfortunate enough to uncover its ancient evil.

Though the bearer of the Nemesis Crown lies slain on the field of battle, so too does the mighty force that fought to claim it. For now, its dark power remains lost to all, awaiting the next fool unfortunate enough to uncover its ancient evil.
The Nemesis Crown grows in power. Whether this is a good thing or not will only become clear in time.

Torn from the cold, dead hands of its previous bearer, {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}, the Nemesis Crown's corruption seeps out in every direction. Proclaimed too dangerous to ever be put to use, it has been cast away instead, sealed beneath countless protections, so that its wickedness may never reappear.

Torn from the cold, dead hands of its previous bearer the Nemesis Crown's corruption seeps out in every direction. Proclaimed too dangerous to ever be put to use, it has been cast away instead, sealed beneath countless protections, so that its wickedness may never reappear.

Forged by the infamous Dawi Runesmith, Alaric the Mad, the Nemesis Crown corrupts all it touches. Isolating every dark thought, it twists the mind of its wearer, leaving them hollowed out by madness. Now a horde of Goblins has uncovered it and claimed its power for themselves! Whatever their intent, death and anarchy are sure to follow.

The bearer of the Nemesis Crown has succumbed to the wounds of battle, and now the ancient artefact rests upon a new brow. As one malevolent power lies defeated, another far more dangerous one, {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}, arises to take its place!

[[i]]The ancient and powerful artefact known as the Nemesis Crown whispers to you again, promising great power should it be taken into your stewardship. New visions flood your mind, revealing a glimpse of its location...[[/i]]\\n\\nThe crown lies near abandoned ruins in an unoccupied region.\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_nemesis_crown_incident_clues}}

May Nurgle bless the horde with further military supremacy!\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_tamurkhans_chieftains_view_panel}}

The remaining candidates for your Chieftains, from the esteemed to the reviled, have revealed themselves – make use of your [[img:icon_dominance]][[/img]] Dominance to recruit them and benefit from their retinues and powers!\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_tamurkhans_chieftains_view_panel}}
A New Chieftain has become available to recruit in the [[col:yellow]]Tamurkhan's Chieftains[[/col]] panel. You have unlocked all Chieftains!

The Maggot Lord’s rising Dominance amasses his decaying warband with fanatical acolytes and twisted monstrosities. Go forth and secure their Fealty!\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_tamurkhans_chieftains_view_panel}}

Following your victory in his final battle, [[col:yellow]]{{tr:land_units_onscreen_name_wh3_dlc25_nur_cha_skin_wolf_werekin_chieftain}}[[/col]] has reached maximum [[img:icon_deference]][[/img]]Fealty as you have garnered his full devotion. May Nurgle bless the horde with further military supremacy!\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_tamurkhans_chieftains_view_panel}}
In the dead of night, Beastmen led by Grukmur take dark vengeance for the loss of their fallen kin, attacking Krom the Crazed while he communes with his Ruinous masters!
Ezar Doombolt's greed trumps his better judgement. He denies Tamurkhan further aid until his ire is quelled! Petulance is so unbecoming of a Chieftain…
Siding with Ezar Doombolt over the zealous Kayzk has garnered Grandfather Nurgle's disapproval. Growth wanes as his gaze shifts from Tamurkhan…
Honour marred, Ezar Doombolt retaliates with suitably heavy ordnance, wiping out the camp's occupants.
Truly crazy, Khargan exults in his madness and hatred, ignoring your command and attacking Ezar Doombolt in the middle of camp. This is not how allies should be treated!

Khargan the Crazed sees compromise as a weakness, and questions your authority. Perhaps next time a show of strength would be more prudent, for such pandering has diminished your control over your Chieftains.
Siding with Mournhowl over the zealous Kayzk has upset the Urfather. Corruption wanes as Nurgle's gaze shifts from Tamurkhan…
Khargan does not take lightly to being reprimanded. He calls out Mournhowl and breaks the wolf's jaw!
Mournhowl is enraged and attacks Ketzak Fimdirach for violating his privacy, mauling him horrifically!
Infections can now be spent to concoct and spread plagues through the world! \\n\\nView the [[sl:campaign_plague_cauldron_panel]]Plagues panel[[/sl]] for more information.

One of your Chieftains has advanced to a higher level of Fealty, increasing your strength and favour in the eyes of Nurgle!\\n\\nYour [[col:yellow]][[i]]Favoured of Nurgle[[/i]][[/col]] Trait has improved. View Tamurkhan’s [[sl:campaign_character_details_panel]]Character Details panel[[/sl]] for more information.

[[i]]Spending her days secluded in her towers and experimenting with rare mystic artefacts, {{tr:land_units_onscreen_name_wh3_dlc25_emp_cha_elspeth_von_draken}} stands ready as a true defender of the Empire.[[/i]]\\n\\n[[i]]Her strength is needed now more than ever, for the {{tr:factions_screen_name_wh3_main_ogr_feastmaster}} Ogres encroach upon Wissenland, while the Vampires to the east pose an ever increasing threat.[[/i]]\\n\\n[[i]]The Countess Emmanuelle von Liebwitz beseeches the Dark Lady for aid![[/i]]\\n\\n[[col:yellow]]Defeat the factions of the {{tr:factions_screen_name_wh3_main_ogr_feastmaster}}, {{tr:factions_screen_name_wh_main_vmp_waldenhof}} and {{tr:factions_screen_name_wh_main_vmp_vampire_counts}} to reveal the Empire’s greater threats.[[/col]]

[[i]]Rumours trickle across the land of an ancient power unearthed; a rising tide of malevolence festering in the heart of the Empire. As danger grows within the lands Elspeth von Draken has sworn to defend, she stands ready to act against whispers manifesting into a deadly threat.[[/i]]\\n\\n[[i]]Elspeth has received a flood of visions, revealing a possible location of a dangerous artefact that she is strongly compelled to seek out: the Nemesis Crown.[[/i]]\\n\\n[[col:yellow]]Elspeth’s visions have revealed a keep, surrounded by mountains.[[/col]]\\n\\n[[col:yellow]]Use any army to search for this location by ending turn with them in the correct region.[[/col]]

[[i]]A Greenskin horde touts control of the Nemesis Crown, an ancient artefact harkening from the times of Sigmar, capable of wreaking untold devastation.[[/i]]\\n\\n[[i]]Elspeth must prepare to strike down this wretched menace the moment their leader is revealed, for the fate of the Empire lies at stake.[[/i]]\\n\\n[[col:yellow]]Defeat the Greenskin army to learn the location of their leader and the crown.[[/col]]

[[i]]The Crown-bearer has been revealed at the head of multiple ravaging armies! Though massacre may await the Imperial militia, Elspeth will defend the Empire at all costs.[[/i]]\\n\\n[[i]]Three formidable Warlords raise tattered banners under the Nemesis Crown's sway – slaying the fiends will weaken the Greenskin menace, leaving the lambs to the lions.[[/i]]\\n\\n[[col:green]]The final battle for the Nemesis Crown is now available![[/col]]\\n\\n[[col:yellow]]Defeat the three Warlords, Gnashrak Spiderclaw, Icky da Nosepicka and Luggn Biggagit to weaken the Greenskin forces in the final battle, or otherwise fight the final battle with them at full strength.[[/col]]

A Tactic has been removed from {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}}.\\n\\n[[col:yellow]]Tactics are unequipped when their duration runs out, or if the required units are no longer part of the army. View this character’s[[/col]] [[sl:campaign_army_panel]]Army panel[[/sl]] [[col:yellow]]to equip a new Tactic.[[/col]]

You have ended your current Contract, deciding it is not worth completing to the Client's satisfaction.\\n\\n[[col:yellow]]If the target faction has not been destroyed, you may choose whether to stay at war with them or not. View the [[sl:campaign_mercenary_contracts_link]]Mercenary Contracts panel[[/sl]] to take on a new Contract.[[col:yellow]]

Your current Contract’s duration has ended, and you have failed to earn the required [[img:icon_contract_points]][[/img]]Client Satisfaction in the allotted time.\\n\\n[[col:yellow]]If the target faction has not been destroyed, you may choose whether to stay at war with them or not. View the [[sl:campaign_mercenary_contracts_link]]Mercenary Contracts panel[[/sl]] to take on a new Contract.[[col:yellow]]

[[i]]The Mercenaries are somewhat sceptical of the proposed contract's articles of payment: chests of gold and dust in equal proportions; meat that no longer looks like meat; equipment which, at first glance, seems to have been snatched at random from some ancient battlefield. Yet these walking, talking bone collections do lend a certain mystique to proceedings that have piqued the company's interest.[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]The Tomb Kings' envoys exhibit no emotion as one of their own is tossed into a simmering cauldron "by mistake". Upon discovering that very same one had the client's contract etched in his bones, they simply advise that the company eat more conscientiously, for biting into a bone imbued with magic might have unexpected consequences. Something in their toneless voices ensures that by the end of the Ogres' feast, not a single bone has been consumed.[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]The Vampire Coast pirates relay their client's terms quickly and disembark without fanfare, leaving some of their... creatures behind. They appear to have once been Ogres, their bodies even bigger now, heads even smaller by comparison, their, er, contents meant to be a part of the mercenaries' nightly feast. In truth, the pirates consider them too volatile for their ships. The Ogres consider them the equivalent of pre-cooked stew.[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]Though the Vampire Coast promises ample rewards, they insist on drawing a map that would lead the Mercenaries to them. The Ogres' protestations are cut short by assurances that the route might garner even more wealth. The pirates are, in fact, certain that it will not, but they themselves have put their Unlives on the line in the face of similarly slim odds, so who knows?[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]The Cold One Knight delivering the contract might have meant to instil fear, or at least respect. Instead, Bruisers need to keep curious Ogres from poking at the horrific beast, as they have not seen, let alone killed or eaten, such a thing before. In the end, the rider simply gallops off in frustration, dropping the contract behind him at the Mercenaries' feet.[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]While Dark Elves obfuscate their plain meanness – as Ogres would call it – by their turgid manner of speech, they make their arrogant ambition with refreshing plainness. Part of that plainness could be due to their intended Mercenary audience, but one suspects they simply enjoy someone else doing their dirty work for them.[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]The messengers tasked with delivering the contract appear highly uncertain. It is not the that they fear being refused and made a meal of, and neither is it that they doubt the contract will be fulfilled (they appear to not care either way). No, it is that they believe the High Elves' rewards provided would be far in excess of anything the Ogres, or anyone else, for that matter, may offer in return.[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]A {{tr:land_units_onscreen_name_wh2_main_hef_cha_loremaster_of_hoeth_0}} has been tasked with delivering the contract accompanied by a {{tr:land_units_onscreen_name_wh2_main_hef_inf_phoenix_guard}} unit. He seems to be mildly irked at his companions, doubtlessly used to travelling in more talkative company – as well as dealing with slightly more dignified counterparts. His painstaking effort in explaining the contract, however, lets him preserve a measure of dignity.[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]The Lizardmen envoy has been achingly particular as to when the contract should be delivered, whom he should give it to and whether it should be received in the right hand or the left. Nothing less would do in the name of the Great Plan. The Mercenaries are nonplussed: could it just be the Good-Enough Plan? Those have always worked well in the past, after all...[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]The Scar-Veteran leading the Lizardmen emissaries is capable of meeting an Ogre's gaze at eye level, which Ogres usually consider a challenge. Before they can issue one, however, he shifts his body slightly, whereupon the rest of the Lizardmen warriors rearrange themselves in a manner vaguely threatening enough for the Mercenaries to remember that, in fact, they have met to come to an agreement, not blows.[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]The absence of Skaven on the morning after the company's feast is even more conspicuous than usual. They certainly were there before, but they are even more certainly not here now. Yet, there are scratch-marks on the cauldron. Is this… writing? A contract?[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]The Skaven who have come to present the terms of the client have, unsurprisingly, been denied access to the cauldron's contents; instead, a few Gnoblars have been persuaded to entertain the envoys by taking part in some pigback jousting upon the visitors' backs, whereupon they are quickly whisked off into the night, screaming in confusion.[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]From the outside, any Dwarf impinging on an Ogre's stomping grounds might seem like an invitation to a literal stomping, but Chaos Dwarfs are well-known to Ogre Mercenaries for both their toughness and their willingness to provide contract work. Their wealth is supremely tempting, their miserly demeanour supremely frustrating. The promise of riches usually prevails.[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]The foul runes carved on the obsidian plate of the contract makes one's eyes bleed, but the terms inscribed on it makes one's eyes weep with avaricious joy also. The rewards are handily etched as images underneath the writing, whose pain-inducing properties might simply be what the Chaos Dwarfs consider the receipt of transaction.[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]Grand Cathay's missive is accompanied by an immaculate line of warriors in finely-lacquered armour, their faces just as impassive. They make no move, waiting for the company's representative to come to them instead. The stalemate continues well into the night, until a Gnoblar drenched in fear-sweat takes the contract and brings it back to the camp.[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]A sudden explosion at dawn has sent the company into an uproar. On the outskirts of the camp, at the bottom of a crater, they find a small jade casket with a contract inside. The Ogres squint at the clear sky in vain. Nevertheless, the shrewder among them feel they're being watched.[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]A company of grizzled Kislevite veterans has delivered an offer from their masters. The Mercenaries are intrigued by the Kislevites' scars and missing limbs. The chief perpetrator seems to be frostbite – but also, too many desperate battles for these leather-skinned men to count on their slightly fingerless hands.[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]The Mercenaries are disappointed to see no Bears of any sort among the Kislevite messengers. The messengers themselves know they could not risk instigating an Ogre-Bear brawl where the only ones seriously hurt would be themselves. Some, however, are tempted to send a delegation consisting solely of Bears next time, for they consider their revered animals at least as strong as an Ogre, and definitely smarter.[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]Disagreements over meat and gold owed are to be expected when Ogre Mercenaries negotiate with… anyone, really, but only when the client is another Ogre tribe does the back-and-forth take on the savoury tang of murderous camaraderie that promises (or threatens) to conclude negotiations without even having spoken of the enemy.[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]While most clients offer Ogre Mercenaries contracts to redress a grievance, be it real or imagined, other Ogres do this as a challenge. They take care to list all the ways in which they have made their puny enemy suffer, something the Mercenaries could not possibly achieve. As reward, they would even stake some of their hard-earned meat and battle prizes. Needless to say, most such contracts are word-of-mouth, and are sealed with a handful of broken teeth.[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]The Wood Elves who deliver the contract are confusingly stoic, to the point where the Mercenaries start wondering whether their masters would miss them if they were to become dinner. Before the troop can make up its mind, a horn rings out in the distance and the strangers are gone as quickly as they'd appeared.[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]The Wood Elves seem annoyed by their mission, idly going over the specifics as quickly as possible, clearly disgusted at being in the presence of Ogres. A few of the Maneaters aren’t appreciating this veiled rudeness but are also aware that the forest is watching them, and one unsavoury move could result in a shower of arrows. Better to just accept the contract and let the bony morsels leave in one piece, this time…[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]The Norscan envoys are nowhere to be seen. The Mercenaries find themselves in the middle of a fresh battlefield, nameless corpses heaped haphazardly at one end. The contract is written in blood and entrails on the ground. Some of it the Ogres have already started cooking, but there is enough left to understand the gist.[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]As soon as the Ogres reach the meeting place, battle is joined. The Norscans scream out their client's demands in between strikes. The Mercenaries are put through its paces but are relieved to find it less of a challenge than if they had to *read* the blasted thing.[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]The Bretonnians delivering the contract are met with an elaborate tale, by way of greeting, of an Ogre who managed to devour an entire Knight Errant, horse, lance and armour included. The envoys' expressions at hearing this would sour even Grail water. And no, even if their rewards include Knightly equipment, they never include the Knight.[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]A complement of glowering Knights watches from the shadows as a single Grail Damsel presents Bretonnia's offer to the company around the campfire. Afterwards, she ventures a tale, as she has heard it is customary among Ogres. Some are loudly impressed, whereas others become inexplicably silent. All rise as she takes her leave.[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]A contingent of Dwarf Slayers has delivered a contract from their Lord. Do they know what's in it? No. Do they care? No. Would they themselves enforce the terms should the Ogres fall short? Probably not – Ogre Mercenaries are not nearly worthy enough to fight Slayers, and a Dragon has been spied some miles hence…[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]The terms are simple and concise: A contract fulfilled would provide ample remuneration (within reasonable bounds). A contract unfulfilled would be added to the Book, with footnotes detailing the various methods of redress to be employed at the client's convenience.[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]As they meet the Imperial delegation, the members of the company are confused as to why one of their number is part of it. Later, it turns out it is not an Ogre Mercenary dressed in scavenged human clothing, but an actual denizen of the Empire. It is unclear whether his presence would predispose them towards or against the offer they are about to receive.[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]The Gold Wizard accompanying the Imperial envoys is almost certainly meant to convey the wealth at the client's disposal, but does everything in his power to express his displeasure at the task, to the collective annoyance of both the Ogre Mercenaries and the Imperials with him. The Burgher in the delegation concludes the negotiations before the Wizard has the chance to transmute the Ogres' cauldron into some prancing, meat-spewing monstrosity.[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]The company finds the Greenskin emissaries bickering amongst themselves some distance outside the camp. Their shouts, their garish paint and their smell constitute a perfectly coordinated assault on the senses. Luckily, Ogres are well-known for possessing the perfect countermeasures to all that, both in scarcity of mind and surfeit of body. The negotiations proceed surprisingly smoothly.[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]The Greenskins' contract is conveyed by a raving Goblin Shaman whose words defy the Mercenaries' collective knowledge of foreign tongues. Upon deciding that what they hear is more akin to the sounds of a dying Squig than it is to speech, they take the piece of parchment from his hand and leave him to his confabulation with the nearby rocks and roots.[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]Relentless hunger and the rule of the strongest are two things that Mercenary Ogres and the Vampire Counts have in common. However, the two hungers are not nearly alike, and neither is their understanding of strength. When they meet, they discover the third, and crucial, thing that binds them: their skill for turning misery into profit.[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

[[i]]A huge pile of meat lies before the company, yet fires will not start. Instead of the now-useless firewood, the Ogres stare at a stone cairn where a Wight King stands and delivers its client's terms, weapons drawn. Although hunger churns in their guts, the Mercenaries do not move. Then, as the creature begins its speech anew, they turn their backs and sullenly start munching on the raw meat. The Wight King continues speaking until early morning when it departs, disappearing mid-sentence.[[/i]]\\n\\n{{tr:ui_text_replacements_localised_text_mercenary_contracts_view_panel}}

You have earned the required [[img:icon_contract_points]][[/img]]Client Satisfaction to complete your current Contract!\\n\\n[[col:yellow]]It will stay active and grant its core rewards once the Contract Duration ends or if it is ended via the [[sl:campaign_mercenary_contracts_link]]Mercenary Contracts panel[[/sl]].\\n\\n[[col:yellow]]Any further [[img:icon_contract_points]][[/img]]Client Satisfaction gained beyond this point will be earned as immediate bonus [[img:icon_treasury]][[/img]]Treasury.

You have made good on your Contract, wreaking all manner of devastation upon the targets and gaining the required [[img:icon_contract_points]][[/img]]Client Satisfaction in the allotted time. This Contract’s rewards are now yours!\\n\\n[[col:yellow]]If the target faction has not been destroyed, you may choose whether to stay at war with them or not. View the [[sl:campaign_mercenary_contracts_link]]Mercenary Contracts panel[[/sl]] to take on a new Contract.[[col:yellow]]
Our [[url:script_link_campaign_ogre_camps]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_ogre_camps}}]]Camp[[/tooltip]][[/url]] has been packed up. It will soon be available to re-deploy in another location.

{{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} has purchased the following units from {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:PrimaryTargetMilitaryForceContext.Name}}! Let's get spendin'!\\n{{CcoCampaignEventIncident:ScriptObjectContext(Format("merc_units_recruited_%d", PrimaryTargetCharacterContext.CQI)).StringValue}}
A Caravan has completed the journey to a far flung trading hub and has sold its cargo.\\n\\n This Caravan will now begin the return journey to your capital.
Local rulers in Altdorf welcome the sight of a trader from far Cathay, and offer up a rare trinket as a sign of good faith.
Your Caravan arrives at the Gate to the Sea. The Dwarfs offer a rare item as a show of respect.
The curious host of Castle Drakenhof awards your Caravan Master with a parting gift.
The dockside traders of Erengrad have heard of Cathay only in legend, and show their respect to fellow merchants with an heirloom weapon.
As the trade deal is finally signed, an unremarkable clerk pledges their service on behalf of Estalia.
As your Caravan made a swift exit from the Frozen Landing, a hag pushes a cloth parcel into your trader’s hands.
The Knights of Gisoreux offer your Caravan Master a parting gift.
Your great standing as a merchant has gained you access to markets of unknown rarity, you acquire an article rumoured to be from Ind!
You strike a deal with the Engineering Guild. The money is good, but you are also left with an item you did not bargain for.
Received in Marienburg’s council of Burgomeisters, your Caravan is met with high honour and awarded the official mark of a merchant-trader.
The wealth brought to poor Novchozy by your Caravan has stirred the gratitude of the local Ataman.
The Imperial Gunnery School welcomes your Caravan into Nuln, offering their latest experiment as a gift.
You have discovered a Cathayan trading Caravan on your lands. Their arrival has brought great riches!
A strange item takes your interest on the market stalls of the Shattered Stone Bay. A keen-eyed Ogre parts with it for a small sum.
Upon reaching your destination, a lowly traveller who you took on out of pity is revealed as the child of a Tilean noble. Safely returned, you are given a reward.
The Winds of Magic are enveloping The Black Pyramid of Nagash, a portent of dark times ahead. Something stirs within...

The eternally damned spirit of Nagash curses the land once more. Legions of once-interred skeletons rise to enact his will: the destruction of all who don't swear fealty to him. They must be stopped, before the self-proclaimed God of the Dead dooms us all!

The eternally damned spirit of Nagash curses the land once more. Elder Vampires are pouring out from the Black Pyramid, leading hordes of restless dead. They must be stopped, before the self-proclaimed God of the Dead dooms us all!

The Dwarfs have decided en masse that it is time to finally settle their grudges -  [[i]]all[[/i]] of them - in a single tide of blade and gunpowder. Whilst some grudges may be justified, others seem to be thinly veiled attempts at a land grab. They are no longer open to diplomacy, so the only solution now is destruction!

Rumours are spreading through the land that the Dwarfs are starting to mobilise. We're getting reports of old alliances breaking and clans turning on their neighbours. Use your time wisely to prepare!

Death and decay taints the Winds of Magic as a bitter feud breaks out among the Vampires, with every major Lord of the Night claiming Neferata's legacy. Now they can only be stopped by capturing all the major sites of power, and putting an end to their dark rituals. See to it!
Dark Magic gathers in the ancestral homelands of the Vampires. Signs of life are disappearing without trace to the curse of Undeath.

It was foolish to be worried about any Skaven gatherings. Other than a few scattered scouts, little has changed on the surface. And yet... and yet... Claw marks where they shouldn't be, scurrying sounds in the night, the ominous glow of Warpstone from distant caves and Underway entrances... Something is afoot.

The treacherous schemes are finally revealed. Fearing the wrath of the Horned Rat, the violent conflict of the clans has been redirected towards the surface-dwellers. Great armies of ratkin are infesting the Under-Empire, spreading plague and ruin to the unfortunate cities above. Die-die all things!
All is quiet today. There are absolutely no reports of enormous armies gathering in the ancient Dwarfen Underway. Such an organised force of Skaven would be preposterous... right?

Rumours are spreading of vile Skaven gathering within reach of Ubersreik, and the locals are requesting help. If you can send an army to deal with the problem, heroes and soldiers alike will swear allegiance to your cause.
Having successfully defeated the skaven incursion, the local mercenary army pledges allegiance to your cause.
Boss wants teef so we iz gunna SMAAAASH! Come 'av a go at us, yer stinky git!
Legions of Greenskins are rallying throughout the old world, eager to prove which tribe is "da best" once and for all. Rumours are spreading that a great Waaagh! is soon to occur.
Vengeance descends upon the living and dead alike, as a new Wild Hunt springs to life. These restless spirits must be stopped, lest you and your people become a sacrifice to Kurnous.
The spirits of the forest grow restless, and scouts report gatherings of hostile Wood Elves amassing in all glades across the land. It would be best to prepare for the approaching conflict.
Glory to you - glory to us! The war will go ever on, for that is the nature of this turbulent world, but for this moment we can claim victory!
Glory to you - glory to us! The war will go ever on, for that is the nature of this turbulent world, but for this moment we can claim victory!

The Tome brings grave news... although previously suffering a loss to Be'lakor at the Forge of Souls, {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} have recovered and are making ready to attack once more! Should they reach the Forge of Souls, your campaign will be lost!

An unnatural aggression takes hold of the populace; a seething frustration that explodes at the slightest provocation. Even the most placid soul becomes as quick to anger as a rabid dog. Soon enough, the fighting begins. The streets are littered with the dazed and beaten, and the gutters run red with blood.

Exploring too deep into an ancient cave system, a forager unwittingly brings back with them a hitherto unknown and devastating disease – one which now spreads like wildfire throughout the populace. Beware the coughing! Spurn the sneezing! Run screaming from the feverish!

A travelling clothier sets up her stall, offering garments tailored so masterfully that they are like a second skin. All who don her garments become consumed by self-obsession, forever admiring their own reflections and refusing all other duties. Undeterred, countless more queue out the door.

Chen – single word, shredding sanity wherever it is spoken. They say a large, black bird was the first to utter it, and now all who hear it soon say nothing else, laughing hysterically as they bark into the ears of those around them. "Chen! Chen! Chen! CHEN!"
Another has succumbed to Chaos – a new Daemon Prince is ready to be recruited!

There is a shudder from the Celestial Palace, and the sound of straining metal, as the Wu Xing Compass works its sorcery. Each warrior suddenly finds within their pocket a chipped stone from the Great Bastion itself – a ward against the Great Enemy, a token of the Emperor’s love.

Chaos has laid waste to Cathay. Yet an opportunity presents itself as their invasion has slowed to a halt as they have become distracted by the ruin and slaughter they have caused. It is time to strike back and drive them back beyond The Great Bastion.
The current invasion has been defeated and the Great Bastion threat level has decreased. It will be some time before Chaos can again threaten the Bastion.
The Dragon Emperor is pleased. An army of Chaos threatening the Great Bastion has been defeated.
The Great Bastion threat level has increased! Chaos gathers. An attack is imminent!
The Great Bastion threat level has increased! Chaos gathers near the [[b]]Dragon Gate[[/b]]. An attack is imminent!
The Great Bastion threat level has increased! Chaos gathers near the [[b]]Snake Gate[[/b]]. An attack is imminent!
The Great Bastion threat level has increased! Chaos gathers near the [[b]]Turtle Gate[[/b]]. An attack is imminent!
The Great Bastion threat level has reached its maximum. The forces amassed beyond the wall attack!

There comes an earth-shaking wail from beneath the Dragon River, where it is said the Spirit Dragon slumbers, guarding Cathay's ancestors. While the Emperor makes no pronouncement, the import is clear – his long-unseen daughter mourns to see the families of her homeland so divided. Reverent minds act accordingly.

Foolishly seeking to unlock the sorcerous potential of a Maw Shard, a rogue Alchemist meets a messy end. However, his failed experiment casts a potent illusion upon all Ogrekind – to Cathayan eyes, the brutes now appear to have the faces of cats. Where once there was fear, there is now amusement.

An Ogre Maneater, long in Cathay's employ, finally journeys back to his homeland, where he shares the spoils of his distant exploits. Particularly popular is a dish named Five-Spiced Monkey Brains (though, in truth, it is minced and marinated pork). His tribe would do almost anything for another taste.

Ogres stalk the Ivory Road! Your soldiers swiftly dispatch them, but are startled to discover that one carries a live woman in a sack. The wild-eyed Alchemist reveals she was captured while journeying to take samples from the Great Maw. Greatly amused, the Ogres had made a pet of her.

The people report sightings of flickering figures in their homes, chanting in oddly familiar voices. One is even certain she saw the faces of her long-dead grandparents. Before these reports can be corroborated, the ancestor spirits – if that is what they are – disappear. In their wake, the land knows harmony.
Harmony is balanced. Both Yin and Yang are working as one.
There is disharmony. Yang is ascendant.
We are now Yin focused. Work to return balance and harmony.

Disaster strikes, as a sudden storm blows a colossal Sky-Junk into a mountainside. The impact shakes loose a legion of long-lost Terracotta Sentinels, stationed immobile since some ancient campaign. Fortunately, many can be restored, while those demolished in the fall can be used to repair others of their kind.

An old woman, garbed in peasant robes, beckons you over with a gnarled finger. Never breaking eye-contact, she presses something into your hands, then bows and walks away. You make to discard the surely worthless trinket – then notice a silver moon inscribed upon it. The mark of the Empress!

The sound of breaking glass dispels the quiet harmony of the Grand Observatory. A peasant lies on the floor, dazed and bruised. The Astromancers are horrified by this intrusion, but soften as the man reveals he was helplessly carried here by lightning-flecked wind. Clearly, Azyr has chosen him.

Your followers have created a [[img:icon_cult]][[/img]]cult in the settlement of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}}, belonging to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}. Now is the time to construct a building to reap the benefits!

Due to the high levels of corruption in the province, a [[img:icon_cult]][[/img]]cult has manifested itself in the settlement of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}}, belonging to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}. Strike now and construct a building here to reap the benefits!

Deep in His bilious garden, Nurgle plucks a cankerous fruit from a wilting tree. In that moment, a lowly fiend in your legion begins to chant in an eerie drone, even as its flesh cracks and oozes, and its eyes fuse into a single, pus-weeping orb.

Somewhere far beyond, Slaanesh knows the ecstasy of satisfaction. Afterwards, as the Perfect Prince slumbers in His forbidden boudoir, the howling sweetness of His dreams touches each and every one of His servants. Sated, they need nothing else for now.

Determined to please Khorne further, his servants elect to brand their own hides with His flaming icon. Their screams are beyond horrifying, and the caustic stench of burning Daemon flesh is unforgettable, but the rite plunges them into an enduring hunger for slaughter, requiring no other sustenance.

There comes a whispered voice in the night, murmuring secrets and prophecies, speaking in tongues both long-forgotten and from far-flung futures. Scores of Daemons instantly lose their minds, while others find their flesh warped into monstrous new forms. This is the Changer’s will, as it was long ago decided.
A new power has been granted by the Blood God. A prince of Daemons is now a prince of Bloodletting!
Bequeathed by the Lord of Decay, the power to summon and spread the most noxious plagues.
The Dark Prince wishes you to become a Darkling Prince. The gift of the silver tongue is yours. Seduce in His name.
As part of the Great Sorcerer’s plans, he has given the boon of teleportation to you, a Prince of lore and magic.

The Fly Lord asks only that His servants perpetuate the cycle of life, death and rebirth, employing disease most foul to grease this eternal wheel. Delighted by your apparent devotion to decay, Grandfather Nurgle blesses each and every one of your warriors with a full-body coating of pulsing cysts and iron-hard callouses.

A score of your hell-sent warriors lie slaughtered, and astride their hacked-apart corpses stands one of their own, screaming in unbridled fury as its very flesh violently reshapes itself. Crimson skin, rippling red muscle, and the acrid tang of hell-fire: the Mark of Khorne, the Blood God.

Nurgle's Rot is a slow death sentence for mortals, but amongst the Urfather's faithful it is a source of strength. The Fly Lord's putrescent devotees are thus delighted by their discovery of a new strain of this divine contagion, one that numbs their senses as it ravages their flesh.

For days there have been sightings of a tiny flame around camp, shifting between indescribable colours. The flame grows steadily, and comes to bear the echo of a face, contorted by manic laughter. It soon sprouts a surfeit of twitching limbs, and a tendril-like tongue. The Raven God has made His play...

Awoken suddenly by nightmarish sounds, you find the skies blackened, the earth littered with bone shards, and Daemons lying bruised and bleeding all around. From above comes an unending rain of skulls, shattering cacophonously as they strike the ground. Khorne has sent His blessing!

A strange calm comes over those who pledge themselves to the Raven. They refuse all food and rest, and work tirelessly. When pressed on the matter, they all chant the same chant: "We want for nothing today, for great Tzeentch has shown us the rewards we will know tomorrow."

Your Daemons will not fight, for they spend every waking moment entwined, raking at their fellows' unholy hides, gasping unspeakable moans. As the vast and fleshy throng eventually shudders into calm, from amongst its tangled limbs emerges a vision of captivating terror. Slaanesh has sent an emissary.

Sin, depravity and degeneracy! Pain, pleasure and excess! Your every thought is dominated by unspeakable desires. It is only once every Daemon in your legion has known your dark embrace that your mind becomes your own again. Far away, in His palace of unending transgression, Slaanesh knows rapture.

The land itself erupts in obsidian spines from far below, some coated in crimson blood, some in noxious bile, others exuding a bewitching, bittersweet fragrance, and others still bearing a shimmering halo of eldritch flame. The Ruinous Powers lay claim to this realm...
Drawn by the scent of blood and smoke, your minions have infested the ruins at {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}}, and the settlement is now yours to control.
The Exalted One is now in command of this army. The Herald has been consumed, but a sliver of his power remains for the new leader to exploit.

{{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} has managed to skirt the maelstrom using their own machinations, and enter Khorne’s realm seeking a Daemon Prince’s soul, thus getting them closer to the Forge and the dying god.

Circumventing the maelstrom, {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} has crossed reality to enter Nurgle’s realm. If they are allowed to reap a Daemon Prince’s soul within it, then they have a better chance of claiming the dying god before you.

Somehow avoiding the maelstrom using forgotten lore, {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} has entered Slaanesh’s realm and will attempt to cull a Daemon Prince’s soul. Should they be successful, then the dying god could be within their grasp.

{{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} has used their own arcane means to bypass the maelstrom and enter Tzeentch’s realm, intent on claiming a Daemon Prince’s twisted soul. If they succeed, they will be a step closer to reaching the dying god before you.
{{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} have challenged the Blood God in His realm and claimed a Daemon Prince’s soul!
{{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} have stolen a Daemon Prince’s soul from Nurgle’s foetid realm.
{{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} have made their way through Slaanesh’s Circles of Seduction and claimed a darkling soul.
A Daemon Prince’s soul has been taken from Tzeentch’s Impossible Fortress by {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}.
Khorne claims back His armaments. The weapon that you claimed from the Blood God's Domain has been returned!
{{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} have been defeated in their challenge against Be'lakor at the Forge of Souls! Though... they will recover, and confront him again in time.
A play has been made in the Great Game and a new God rises to the fore, achieving Ascendancy over his Ruinous brothers.\\n\\nKhorne has gained Ascendancy… for now.
A play has been made in the Great Game and a new God rises to the fore, achieving Ascendancy over his Ruinous brothers.\\n\\nNurgle has gained Ascendancy… for now.
A play has been made in the Great Game and a new God rises to the fore, achieving Ascendancy over his Ruinous brothers.\\n\\nSlaanesh has gained Ascendancy… for now.
A play has been made in the Great Game and a new God rises to the fore, achieving Ascendancy over his Ruinous brothers.\\n\\nTzeentch has gained Ascendancy… for now.

Out of the forests they emerge, the horned beasts that stand upright in a vile parody of man. They are the Cloven Ones, the Children of Chaos and they have come for us; to tear down our civilisation! The warherds are migrating, and destroying anything in their path. Defend yourselves from the Beastmen’s wrath.

The Orcs are coming… not the ‘sophisticated’ bunch that hangs out in captured Dwarfholds, but the more ‘rural’ boyz that wander the southern Badlands. Yes, a nomadic horde of extra-fighty Savage Orcs are close and could threaten your forces. Best be proactive against this lot before Mork (or Gork) leads them right into your realm.

A rustling from the jungle’s depths grows louder… the Lizardmen have emerged! Roused by some unknown impetus, their threat cannot be taken lightly. Stay vigilant against these cold-blooded foes, for their motivations are unfathomable.

A Norse Marauder in your legion loudly demands Daemonic power in reward for his service. Upon his eighth such protestation, there follows the sounds of cracking bone and liquefying flesh. Where he once stood gleams a gift from Khorne, imbued with dark power. It emits a distant but constant scream.

A Norscan Shaman reports a vision of a far-off kingdom razed to ash, its every inhabitant slaughtered, of nothing left but a mountain of skulls. Though none know where this land is, the joyous news of Khorne's distant triumph means countless Daemons jockey for the opportunity to achieve similar here.

No realm can be truly considered cleansed of life by merely scourging its surface. In sewers and caverns the Skaven lurk, always. Eight thousand barrels of boiling blood solve the problem neatly. As countless vermin are roasted alive in their foul nests, the land itself becomes a monument to Khorne.

Most sane mortals would flee rather than face Khornate might, but some suffer the affliction of pride. So it is that a Greenskin horde surges toward camp, their Warboss loudly boasting "dese spiky gitz ain't so tuff!" Unsurprisingly, the ‘spiky gits’ prove tough indeed. The bounty is plentiful.

The forges in the Daemonium are powdered by the fiery breath of Hashut, a fire  hotter than the stars. The weapons forged within are as powerful as any trinket cast by any Dwarf god or Elven smith of legend.

You stumble upon an Ogre camp. A Butcher escapes the slaughter by promising untold power. He slices and stews the entrails of his fallen kin, creating a foaming red broth which causes hide to harden and muscle to swell. Though useful, all sorcery offends Khorne, and so the Butcher is slain.

A lowly Bloodletter has fled camp – ⁠unthinkable that it would betray the Murder Lord! Eight days and eight nights later, it wordlessly returns, bearing a cart spilling over with colossal Ogre skulls. There is the sudden, acrid stench of burning skin, and then the Daemon stands remade, rewarded by Khorne himself.

Tired of waiting for the next battle, a troop of Bloodletters storm out of camp. They maraud across the land, slaughtering without discretion, their rage growing with each kill. Ultimately, they turn upon each other. Though none survive, word of their brutal deeds inspires others to similar feats of carnage.

The Skull of the First glowers high above Khorne's realm. Some say it was Khorne’s first kill. A trophy he kept in the sky. Deep within its eye socket is a shard of the weapon that killed the First. Such a blade would surely be one of the greatest in all of creation?
{{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} has harvested a colossal skull pile. The fallen warriors can now be put to good use, in the Blood God's name!

Khorne's Daemons on occasion find entire cities deserted, their inhabitants abandoning all that they have rather than face the blood harvest. In such a ghost town you discover a single man, draped in entrails, howling praise to the Axefather. Behind every door is a sundered corpse.

As one, unbidden, dozens of Daemons begin to chant. "Blood for the Blood God! Skulls for the Skull Throne! BLOOD FOR THE BLOOD GOD! SKULLS FOR THE SKULL THRONE!" They continue this tirelessly for days, then suddenly all drop dead. There is a laugh like thunder, and the skies blacken.

Dangling from the Tree of Souls are all manner of weapons and ordnance. Perching – and oft times flying around the tree – are a murder of ghostly crows, the victims of the weapons that hang from its branches. Will you add to the flock?

Khorne's legion is waylaid upon a mountainside by Dwarfs. Though the wretches are soon parted from their skulls, their trap is sprung - a hidden explosive hurls a dozen Daemons down the mountain, a mile-long fall none could survive... none save a Bloodthirster. As its bones knit, its might only grows.

There are challengers waiting afore the Wrathgate, eager to prove their worth and trigger the infinitesimally-small chance that mighty Khorne will turn His head and gaze out from the Brass Citadel and notice them. Until that time, the weapon racks by the gates are fully stocked.

Madame Valentina, a singularly fearsome Ice Witch, retired years ago. But she has spent the time since tutting at falling standards, at Ice Maidens who barely know Frost Blade from Crystal Cloak, and she can stand no more. When she raps furiously upon the Ice Court’s doors, none dare refuse her.

For as long as the Ice Court and the Orthodoxy have vied for support, the stability of the Motherland has hung in balance. Yet as both sides progress towards their aims, they have become more fickle in what they demand for their Boons.
The Ursun Revivalists faction led by Boris the Red has joined the fray. For the sake of the Motherland, the Red Tzar is willing to join your cause. Will you confederate?

The Red Tzar is back and ready to defend Kislev once more. Never mind any constitutional issues this raises, first and foremost Kislev must be protected. He is ready to lead an army at your command!\\n\\nFind Boris in the Lord Recruitment panel.

Our low level of [[img:icon_devotion]][[/img]]Devotion has resulted in a Chaos uprising in the region of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}}! Rally a defence immediately, the threat must be stamped out!

The Patriarchs descend upon every home, rooting through drawers and overturning bookshelves in search of any hint of heresy. Countless Kislevites are dragged from their beds and executed. Who can say how many were innocent? Nevertheless, purity – or, at least, terrified obedience – is restored.

Feeding War Bears is an expensive business – the beasts consume their own body weight in meat daily. The discovery of an enormous Slaaneshi cult hiding in Erenegrad's sewers is thus an occasion for celebration rather than dismay. Blasphemy is duly purged, and the bears sleep well.

Many believe that the Motherland is alive, and loves her people as they love her. When disease claims the lives of every man, woman and child in five stanitsas, the icy wind takes on a new timbre, one that sounds like a sorrowful howl. The land will surely make amends.

Though Kislev stands as one in the eyes of the world, in truth the Motherland is riddled with sedition. An avaricious Boyar is the latest to show his hand, bribing dozens of Atamans to reject your rule. Once your Akshina pay him a midnight call, the Atamans abruptly regain their loyalty.

Your Lancers bring you the bones of a long-lost Tzar, discovered while patrolling the oblast. Into a reliquary box they go, holy relics of an ancient war to defend Kislev’s vast borders. Inspired by this proof that their rulers too sacrifice everything for the Motherland, your legions take heart.

Officially, the Ice Court only accepts young women of noble lineage, for only they deserve its timeless wisdom. Exceptions are sometimes made, though none may talk of it. When a farmer beseeches the Court, offering a thousand saddlebags of blood-stained gold, his daughter is accepted without question.

While trapping the scrawny rabbits of the Oblast, a huntsman is set upon by a wandering bear. The attack is beyond horrendous, his wounds countless and grievous. Yet, impossibly, he lives. It takes him 20 days to drag his broken body home. His survival is miraculous: truly, Ursun loves him.

Threatened with damnation by their local Patriarch, the people of a far-flung stanitsa work tirelessly to construct a colossal cathedral to Ursun. When they run out of building materials, they dismantle their own homes. When dozens die from exposure, the Patriarch chastises the faithlessness of those who yet live.

Your plague-scientists have been busy. From their squalid laboratories they birth a brand new contagion, one they proudly dub 'Raven Rot'. Remorselessly, the pox ravages eldritch feathers and chews at ectoplasmic flesh. Truly, it is a beautiful disease, one that silences the arrogant bluster of the Changer’s iridescent slaves.

Your pock-marked children pick idly at their own scabs as they await the next battle. After a time, they fall into a strange and silent trance, and continue picking until their entire hides hang off them in grisly ribbons. As their ruined flesh knits, it hardens into thick, body-wide callouses.

A storm darkens the skies, but there is no lightning – instead, there comes a hail of man-sized, pus-filled seeds. As they implant themselves in the earth, it becomes iron-hard and sprouts vast and pungent fungal foundations. Praise be to Nurgle, for He shares His garden's bounty!

While tallying the bodies after the routine infection of a human village, your Maggotkin discover a lone survivor, trapped beneath a pile of putrefied corpses. The wild-eyed man, his skin crisscrossed with weeping lesions but otherwise no worse for wear, kisses the Daemons' festering feet, declaring Nurgle his saviour.

Your oldest Plaguebearer has fought on even as the flesh dripped from its worm-eaten bones. But its putrefying frame can hold together no longer, and the Daemon collapses into a pool of foul-smelling mulch. There is a chuckle from afar, and the bilious body-juice suddenly reforms itself, hardier than ever.

An uncommonly bloated Plague Toad is drawn helplessly to the befoulment of a nearby sewer, but cannot squeeze itself through the entry grate. With a final terrible lunge, it wrenches itself across - tearing its vast belly open in the process. The countless black maggots within surge into the local water supply.

The droning of Nurgle's Plaguebearers is feared across the land, for all know it heralds lingering, fever-wracked death. However, an unusually enterprising Tallyband drift from their usual monotone and chant their chilling dirge in a hitherto-unheard frequency – one which immediately loosens the bowels of all for miles around.

Many equate Nurgle with death, but this is to misunderstand His intent. He desires rebirth, so that more death may follow. So it is that He raises the bones of the long-dead, and from them sprouts bilious flesh. Nurgle's newest children strike up their buzzing drone, and the cycle begins anew.

The earth of every town, every village, every field and every forest simultaneously sprouts a single Nurgling. The tiny Daemons stand stock-still, their rictus grins never changing. On the seventh day of this, all suddenly burst, releasing an immense cloud of flies that quickly disperse, turning the very skies yellow.

Morrslieb grows full, casting its sickly green light across the land. The Fly Lord’s children rejoice, for contagion thrives under the Chaos moon’s cold shadow. The rotted legion erupts in fresh sores and, in horrifying unison, coughs a constant cough, spraying fountains of plague-ridden spittle with every phlegmy bark.

The camp is woken by the sound of a colossal belch, a booming, watery blast that echoes across the mountains. In its malodorous, gassy wake, birds fall from the sky, and even Rhinox slump unconscious, but the tribe is invigorated by the foul stench. The Great Maw has sent its blessing!

It begins as a drinking competition between bored Bulls, but they make laughably short work of all the ale in camp. Desperate measures are thus required. Somehow, someone provides a steaming cauldron of lava. Dozens die, roasted from the inside, but one Bull merely belches calmly and requests another sip.

In search of his fourth consecutive midnight feast, one of your followers wanders off into the mountains. He returns days later, bloodied, horribly scarred and missing several fingers, and idly gnawing at a colossal Stonehorn haunch. When questioned, he merely shrugs, then demands a snack.
Our [[url:script_link_campaign_ogre_camps]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_ogre_camps}}]]camp[[/tooltip]][[/url]] has been destroyed! Perhaps a new one can be set up?
Factions have approached you with bounties... should you choose to accept them. Carrying out one of them will reward you with riches and favour!

An enterprising Slaughtermaster hits upon the idea of fashioning crude, oversized slip-on noses and ears from leftover scraps of hide. Desirous of these absurd prosthetics, countless Gnoblars flock to your cause – for in their abhorrent society there is no greater sign of station than a bulbous snout and mammoth lugs.

One of your Butchers laces his latest dish with oddly-glowing mushrooms from the deepest caves. The tribe who consumes it soon enters a state of euphoria. As one, they begin to dance, their thunderous footsteps toppling trees and shaking boulders from mountains. Even the very shadows retreat from the cacophony.

The whelp's scrawny limbs and wasted gut had seen it banished, doomed for death or, worse, a half-life as a mutant Gorger. But years later, the child returns, now colossal in size, his swaying belly daubed in bloody sigils. Wordlessly, he prepares a great feast for the tribe. None object.
