Those farmsteads unfortunate enough to be proximate to your tribes have long accepted that the price of their survival is eye-wateringly high. The great day has rolled around once again, and when your followers eventually stir from their grease-stained beds, they are presented with veritable mountains of slaughtered lambs and calves.

Your scouts stumble across a secret valley, home to a diminutive and hitherto undiscovered equine species. Their hides are all the colours of the rainbow, their manes are long and vibrant, their eyes are huge and kindly. Truly, they are a wonder. By nightfall, every one of them is in the pot.

Though Gnoblars are highly irritating creatures, the larger ones have occasional moments of brilliance. One of your favourites takes it upon itself to spread a rumour that consuming the gizzard of a Daemon will make one's gut double in size. To say the tribe is motivated would be an understatement.

A wandering Hunter shares his tall tales with the tribe. In one, he claims to have trapped and eaten a dragon, and that the taste was beyond compare - like the most succulent chicken marinated in the finest spices. The tribe is instantly decided: they must experience this singular flavour themselves.

Your henchmen drag an unusually lucid Gorger before you. Unlike its solitude-maddened kin, the elephantine, sinewy horror will obey basic commands. This proves particularly useful during contract negotiations. A mere snap of the fingers will see the other party’s head torn from their shoulders – a superior rate is thus guaranteed.

Determined to prove himself hungrier than a rival from another tribe, one of your Tyrants arranges an eating contest. From dawn ‘til dusk, both Ogres cram endless meats into their gore-strewn maws. When both simultaneously retch up enough pink, chunky vomit to fill a small lake, a respectable draw is declared.

Stones shake loose from a nearby mountain as something hurtles down its side, carving a vast furrow, crushing wildlife and uprooting trees. It rolls helplessly into camp, scattering Gnoblars like skittles, and when it finally draws still is revealed to be an Ogre Hunter, flat on his back but otherwise unconcerned.

The rifts have gone. The Daemonic hosts that crossed the maelstrom through them have lost their link to the Chaos Realms. Without such power to sustain themselves, the hosts will quickly dissipate, so want to take as many souls with them as possible!\\n\\nReady your defences – the Daemons from the rifts attack!
The rifts that bypass the maelstrom into the Chaos Realms are not stable doorways! They will disperse from the mortal world shortly and not return until Ursun roars again.

The rifts that bypass the maelstrom into the Chaos Realms are not stable doorways! They only remain manifest as long as the dying god’s roar reverberates across the mortal plane. Once dispersed, they will not return until Ursun howls again.

{{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} has dedicated his gathered power and twisted soul to the Blood God, Khorne.\\n\\n[[i]]“I will kill, I will Maim, I will BURN for Him. Blood for the Blood God!”[[/i]]

{{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} has dedicated his gathered power and twisted soul to the Great Lord of Decay, Nurgle.\\n\\n[[i]]“I have found my true Grandfather, and He is a generous God.”[[/i]]

{{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} has dedicated his gathered power and twisted soul to the Dark Prince, Slaanesh.\\n\\n[[i]]“I was seduced to the cause of the One Who Thirsts, and now I hunger for secrets to keep.”[[/i]]

{{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} has dedicated his gathered power and twisted soul to the Great Deceiver, Tzeentch.\\n\\n[[i]]“My fate is entwined with the Changer of Ways. It always was; I just didn’t know it until now.”[[/i]]

{{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} refuses to be anyone’s servant. The Ruinous Powers have no hold over him.\\n\\n[[i]]“I am no puppet, they cannot fetter me! The power is mine alone!”[[/i]]
It is done! {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} has completed the Unholy Manifestation.
You have called upon the Blood God and He has heard your cry! Let the bloodshed commence...

We have invoked the [[sl:campaign_motherland]]Motherland[[/sl]] in the name of Dazh! Ensure that we focus our efforts on constructing [[sl:campaign_buildings]]buildings[[/sl]] and [[img:icon_supporters]][[/img]][[sl_tooltip:campaign_supporters_track]]Supporters[[/sl_tooltip]] will flock to our cause.

We have invoked the [[sl:campaign_motherland]]Motherland[[/sl]] in the name of Salyak! Ensure that we focus our efforts on gaining [[sl:campaign_character_skills]]ranks[[/sl]] with our [[img:icon_general]][[/img]][[sl:campaign_lords]]Lords[[/sl]] and [[img:icon_hero]][[/img]][[sl:campaign_heroes]]Heroes[[/sl]] and [[img:icon_supporters]][[/img]][[sl_tooltip:campaign_supporters_track]]Supporters[[/sl_tooltip]] will flock to our cause.

We have invoked the [[sl:campaign_motherland]]Motherland[[/sl]] in the name of Tor! Ensure that we focus our efforts on fighting [[sl:campaign_battles]]battles[[/sl]] and [[img:icon_supporters]][[/img]][[sl_tooltip:campaign_supporters_track]]Supporters[[/sl_tooltip]] will flock to our cause.

We have invoked the [[sl:campaign_motherland]]Motherland[[/sl]] in the name of Ursun! Ensure that we focus our efforts on expanding our territory and [[img:icon_supporters]][[/img]][[sl_tooltip:campaign_supporters_track]]Supporters[[/sl_tooltip]] will flock to our cause.
It is done! {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} has completed the Unholy Manifestation.
{{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} has committed their surplus meat to the Great Maw. He and his army will now enjoy its blessing!
{{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} has committed their surplus meat to the Great Maw. He and his army will now enjoy its blessing!
{{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} has committed their surplus meat to the Great Maw. He and his army will now enjoy its blessing!
{{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} has committed their surplus meat to the Great Maw. He and his army will now enjoy its blessing!
It is done! {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} has completed the Unholy Manifestation.

A time for rejoicing! We have performed the [[url:script_link_campaign_pleasurable_acts]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_pleasurable_acts}}]]pleasurable act[[/tooltip]][[/url]] at the Pleasure Arena in the [[url:script_link_campaign_provinces]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_provinces}}]]province[[/tooltip]][[/url]] of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:PrimaryTargetSettlementContext.ProvinceContext.Name}}.

A time for rejoicing! We have performed the [[url:script_link_campaign_pleasurable_acts]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_pleasurable_acts}}]]pleasurable act[[/tooltip]][[/url]] at the Pleasure Hunt in the [[url:script_link_campaign_provinces]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_provinces}}]]province[[/tooltip]][[/url]] of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:PrimaryTargetSettlementContext.ProvinceContext.Name}}.

A time for rejoicing! We have performed the [[url:script_link_campaign_pleasurable_acts]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_pleasurable_acts}}]]pleasurable act[[/tooltip]][[/url]] at the Pleasure Party in the [[url:script_link_campaign_provinces]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_provinces}}]]province[[/tooltip]][[/url]] of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:PrimaryTargetSettlementContext.ProvinceContext.Name}}.
The Great Schemer has blessed {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} - their movement range has been restored.
The fate of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} has been changed! A rebellion has been manifested, causing disruption for {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}!

A sudden rebellion has appeared in {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} through no fault of our own! Tzeentchian manipulations of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:PrimaryTargetFactionContext.Name}} are at work.
He is said to be the Weaver of all Fates, and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} now succumbs. This army has been stopped in their tracks, unable to move for their turn.
Our army has been halted in their tracks! Scheming performed by the Tzeentchian faction of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:PrimaryTargetFactionContext.Name}} has halted us for this turn.

Pawns found in the settlement of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}}, belonging to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}, have opened their gates for us! Now is the time to strike the city, in the name of the Changer of Ways.

The gates to our settlement, {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}, have been opened against our will! Tzeentchian manipulations of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:PrimaryTargetFactionContext.Name}} are at work, garrison the city in preparation of an assault!
The Great Schemer has seen all – territory belonging to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} has been unveiled to us!
The Sorcerer God has taken a great interest in the faction of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}. Their intentions have been revealed to us.

The Changer of Ways has cast His watchful eye upon {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}}, belonging to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}. Their line of sight is now being provided to us.
It is done! {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} has completed the Unholy Manifestation.
It is done! {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} has completed the Unholy Manifestation.
Your character has reached their destination following their voyage along the Sea Lane.

A Keeper of Secrets brings you a shimmering crystal, which they claim houses the frozen soul of an Old One, captured at the anguished moment of death, forever voicing their final scream. While it is almost certainly a mere Slann soul, such a gift is nevertheless irresistible to any Ruinous servant.

Your Fiends learn to howl in a hypnotic harmony that implants an overwhelming suggestion into the minds of all around. Across the land, hands claw feverishly at belt buckles and blouse buttons, walls shake and beds break. Calls for order fall upon deaf ears, for all are lost in bliss.
This faction has let the temptations of Slaanesh lure them to the very brink of damnation. You may send your disciples to attempt to dominate them and force them into vassalage.
The lure of the Dark Prince is potent indeed. {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} have forsaken their independence and are now enslaved to the will of Slaanesh.

Mutation is usually the bailiwick of Tzeentch, but it has its uses for Slaanesh. There is a moan from beyond, and your followers sprout gossamer, lavender tendrils. Wherever they tread, their new fronds help themselves to flesh, caressing and lashing, clasping and tantalising, bringing shivers of ecstasy to all around.

One of your Daemonettes exudes an irresistible new scent. Countless mortals are helplessly enraptured by it, trailing after the Daemon with wild-eyes and drooling mouths. It is child's play to lead them all over a cliff edge. Delighted by this vision of broken, wailing bodies, Slaanesh grants a glorious reward.

In dreams, the Perfect Prince touches every mind, granting fevered visions of their darkest desires. The strongest are buoyed by these indescribable peaks of sensation, awakening fulfilled like never before, but the weakest cannot endure. Their spent, desiccated forms crumble, and the very land feeds upon their tormented souls.

It has been too long since your Daemonettes last slaked their desires. Frustrated, six of them dance towards the nearest mortal settlement, where they adopt the forms of beauteous men and maidens, unclothed and glistening. Hundreds flock to them, and know an agonised rapture they will forever crave to experience again.

In a moment of indulgence, you grant one of your followers the honour of becoming tonight's concubine. Basking in the afterglow of pleasure and suffering beyond all mortal imagining, they henceforth carry themselves with unshakeable confidence, convinced of their own greatness.

A man approaches your gates, begging to be let in. When he is ignored, he hammers a dozen iron hooks into your walls – which, with a great deal of screaming, he manages to hang himself from, by his own flesh. He shall be most welcome here.

Your perfumiers have designed a new scent to confound the senses, one which causes all those who inhale it to helplessly bellow their deepest desires aloud. By dousing themselves in this delicious fragrance, your Daemonettes are granted all the insight they need to bewitch their weak-minded foes.

A euphoric compulsion takes hold of every soul in the land, and they each proudly send you a missive containing their darkest, guiltiest secret. When reason returns to them, they swear unwavering subservience – in exchange for a promise that their shameful truths shall never be revealed.

An eerie freneticism falls upon your scribes as they study their tomes, refusing rest and sustenance. As they read, their craniums swell and swell, until their engorged brains spill from their skulls – yet still they read. On the ninth morning, their vast minds consume the rest of their malnourished forms.

Where does the Eternity Stair lead? Some say only the Great Architect truly knows, but those who climb at least to the Ninth Paradox will glean secrets, allowing them to navigate the outskirts of the Crystal Labyrinth.
The roosts of the Watchers offer great vantage to watch over myriad worlds and realities. From there it is said, the ninth layer of the Crystal Labyrinth is revealed.

Wealth is a dull necessity in the mortal realm, but there are ways to make its acquisition more entertaining. Deep in His Impossible Fortress, the Changer inscribes a flaming rune into the very air. Far away, a single ear of each of your followers is transmuted into solid gold.

Within the Heavenward Halls are games of skill, mystery, mental and the physical. Each game won allowing the candidate more time within the Crystal Labyrinth to find a path toward the Impossible Fortress.

The Iron Knight knows the inner passages of the Crystal Labyrinth, but is cursed by Tzeentch to never walk beyond the boundaries of his Citadel. Perhaps a bargain can be sought – his knowledge in exchange for a way to break the curse? We know what breaks godly curses...

Falsehoods and secrets are the weapons of a true liar, but for every deceit there must be a chance of truth, for if you only ever spill lies then the listener will quickly tire and lose hope. Find the truth... find a way through the maze, it is hidden in untruth.

Nine of your Pink Horrors spontaneously combust from within, each releasing a shower of giggling, dancing sparks as it expires. After starting numerous fires, the sparks eventually calm themselves and draw still, shifting between luminous hues that defy description. Suddenly, they surge towards each other and coalesce into something new...

Without warning, nine city-sized blue and yellow runes manifest in the skies. The moment they disappear, the same rune carves itself into the left cheek of all who witnessed it. Their eyes turn immediately white, their mouths seal over and they stand stock-still, awaiting instruction.

Those of your followers lucid enough to care report strange behaviour from their own shadows. The shades appear to move of their own accord, never quite mirroring the actions of their casters. Soon enough they tear themselves free and stand upright – unnerving yet loyal two-dimensional replicas of those who bore them.

In the Ruins is the Dead King and on his lips a whisper of knowledge lost for generations, a way to the heart of the maze and the Impossible Fortress at its centre. For that is why the Dead King no longer lives – he possesses knowledge that Tzeentch does not want told...

As one, your followers begin to skip in and out of existence. One second they are there, one second they are not, then they reappear, and so forth. With each reappearance, they sport fresh new feathers, resplendent in blue and gold, and speak in a different tongue.

There comes the sound of screaming from the gaol, where a slew of captured mortals await their fate. Fascinated, you watch as their skin peels itself from their bones, then tears and arranges itself into hundreds of identically-shaped pages. Upon their fleshy surfaces, the Raven God's sorcerous word appears.

A man shambles towards camp, loudly remonstrating himself. As he draws closer, another reason for his strange, stumbling gait is made clear. Strapped to his body are dozens of freshly-severed appendages and heads, intended to form a crude, gruesome simulacrum of the flesh-warping gifts Tzeentch grants His chosen.

There is the sudden sound of rushing wind, and one of your most trusted slaves abruptly vanishes, leaving only scorched footprints. For nine hours they are gone - then reappear in the exact same spot, now two score years older and boasting of the countless battles they have fought.

A swarm of shimmering blue-pink sigils appears suddenly upon every available surface, each one contradicting the last. Some who gaze upon them strike up uncontrolled screaming, while others chant in a tongue unrecognisable to even Tzeentch's most trusted servants. It is then that the sigils begin to whisper.
The Changer is impressed. He'll remember you.
Tweak the merchants dreams. They'll be your willing patrons.
They shall answer your muster… They will have no choice.
Ah, so it's answers you crave? Well, we have all the answers here.
Look upon the lords and ladies. Don't they look so dapper!
We make them live nine lives in one day.
Embrace the Architect's influence, let his taint smother you.
Whispers of Tzeentch ensure many willing warriors shall join your ranks.
A gift of magical trappings lies in your future.
Strengthening and waning in unison with the multifarious climes above, the Deeproots are now available for travel between Magical Forests.

It was on Arghus, the lost Sky-titan's skull, that Nurgle created His most disgusting phage. Thankfully, He has yet to unleash it upon the mortal world. It is from this plague that Poxfulcrum has developed a powerful immune response which is now yours.
You have travelled to the catacombs deep under the Eternal Swamps, the lair of the Maggot Lord. From its secretions, Poxfulcrum has created immunity to many of Nurgle's deadliest diseases.
The swollen boughs and rotting roots of the Great Tree reach far across the Realm of Chaos, yet it is the sap we need to gain more immunity from the many fungal infections concocted by Father Nurgle.

The most virulent of islands – where else to get the best strain of immunity than at the heart of the disease? Poxfulcrum guides you, and by the time you have woven your way from the Isle, its diseases lose their potency.

The true power of the Cabal is on full display, you have been granted a powerful boon from the Cult allowing your recruitment and construction efforts to increase dramatically.\\n\\nThis is a stark reminder that this Cult is not to be underestimated, and at least for now your pact with them is paying dividends.

The true power of the Cabal is on full display, the enemy force that has occupied one of your settlements has been utterly destroyed and the region returned to you.\\n\\nThis is a stark reminder that this Cult is not to be underestimated, and at least for now your pact with them is paying dividends.

The true power of the Cabal is on full display, after having conquered a region you have also taken control of the entire province, these regions previous inhabitants are dumbfounded as to the power you seem to wield.\\n\\nThis is a stark reminder that this Cult is not to be underestimated, and at least for now your pact with them is paying dividends.

The true power of the Cabal is on full display, one of your enemies has been utterly destroyed, there armies have been crushed and their settlements turned to ruins.\\n\\nThis is a stark reminder that this Cult is not to be underestimated, and at least for now your pact with them is paying dividends.

The Cabal's plans are complete and where once the Cult simply left quietly in the night they now depart in kind but with one key difference, a message delivered directly to your door:\\n\\n"We wanted the world... and now thanks to you we will take it."

As the morning light dawns an absence is first felt and then keenly noticed, the Tower of the Cabal is nowhere to be found. The Cult has left, seemingly in the middle of the night, their plans have progressed to the point where it appears as though their presence in our lands no longer serves them, at least for now.

Frighteningly, the ravenous appetites bestirred by this preternatural egress are not slaked by indulgence; instead, they flare up with burning intensity and grow ever more depraved, threatening to benight all sensibilities under an opaque shroud of sinister cravings.

Despite their assurances to the contrary, the Covenant's repugnant studies have breached their confines; a virulent contagion now spreads throughout the region. Warped and feculent, the eccentrics wasting away in this lair of nightmarish experimentation still insist on the sacrosanctity of their suppurating wounds.

Disaster strikes. In their impudence, the Covenant has unleashed a mephitic plague across your lands, trailing suffering in its wake. Pox-ridden acolytes allege that their stores of bloated carcasses were merely part of a grandiose gift that only the controlled presence of carrion could bestow. Surely, the source of this pestilence must be scoured from the earth!

The Covenant has succeeded. Their hidden agenda is brought to sickly light as missives flood in from lands near and far: a catastrophic scourge has been unleashed through their profane organisation. Its horrifying hallmark is now seen in every land: a mound of plague-ridden corpses undergoing a horrific amalgamation, its bulk suffused into a writhing mantle of flesh and the fleeting impressions of a grimace, equal parts pain and reverence. Now and then, the surface morphs into grotesque ridges and hollows, and a face slowly emerges near the top; its jaw distended, forever split into an eerie, drooling moan toward the uncaring heavens.\\n\\nChillingly, every report ends the same: "This is the tenth such flesh-heap we have seen today."

An unusual site has been discovered near one of your settlements, warranting an investigation to determine its potential benefit. As with any unexpected presence on your land, you have the option to remove it, though at a cost. However, if deemed valuable or of interest, this place can be left undisturbed. Assessing its worth is essential in deciding your next course of action.

When demolishing the old Myrmidian Monastery, your workers discover a small cavity in the foundations of the building, with a locked chest buried deep within. Inside is a bundles of dusty old scrolls. The language written on them is far too complex to immediately decipher, so their purpose remains unknown. However, your scholars will persevere and uncover its meaning. In the meantime, they postulate that those who went to such great lengths to conceal this item may now be lost to time, along with their secrets, and it may take many lifetimes for this writing to finally be understood.\\t

Staring at the mesmerising pattern on the walls of the Purple Hand's now hollowed-out coven, you recall how language strained under their undulating voices into a near-foreign dissonance. Veiled in such cacophony, their assurances were hard to trust – or indeed, to discern as promises at all.\\n\\nAssenting to their hypnotic practices and curious enough to dabble, you have wrested a maddeningly simple cypher from the fluorescent vortex of their conversations. It alone was able to reveal the contents of the irregularly cut piece of vellum resting on the sermon dais.\\n\\nThe elegant, shifting script is unnervingly direct: "Your assistance was instrumental. Our Grand Design unfolds. We shall see you again... very shortly."

As they planned, the Purple Hand have begun to spread further across the world, selecting a new settlement within which to establish a hideout. It is there that their Cultists continue their secret work - what it is, exactly, you still do not know.\\n\\nIn return for your leniency the Cult does at least offer you a small gift.

From beneath a sea-bitten tricorn nested in a matted snarl of hair, the shifty gaze of this hirsute vagabond probes for any sign of gullibility as he spins his captivating yarn.\\n\\nHis proposition, when it comes, is a simple one. He has heard of your 'vault' and requires a discreet place to store his recent acquisitions. He gestures to the gem-studded casing of his ill-got gains, offering a hefty sum for your trouble. But as he speaks, you cannot help but wonder: is the true price the gold he offers, or the inevitable wrath of whomever owned this treasure first?

The Cult of the Yellow Fang has sent a messenger from their sewer hideout. He hands over a chest to a guard firmly clutching his sword, who stops short of drawing it and instead peers inside. Amongst the items inside is a scroll. Once unravelled, a message can just about be made out, scribbled in poorly-formed sentences... "With thanks from your local Yellow Fang friend and ally... Please accept this gift as a token of my appreciation for all efforts relating to 'you know what'...". Unfortunately there's no explanation of exactly which efforts he is referring to. However, the message does appear to be genuine, and what's more, what is inside the chest is quite a strange gift!

While passing through your lands, your forces are approached by a wine merchant, a middle-aged lady calling herself Marlene. Although she appears somewhat aged, it is clear that there's a youthful vigour about her, perhaps beyond what might be expected. In fact, such curiosity is soon confirmed as she offers to sell some of what she calls her "Dreamwine" for a very reasonable price, explaining that drinking it brings good health, long life and a youthful appearance. A small amount of coin is exchanged for the dark, syrupy vintage and she soon leaves, heading in the direction of the nearby vineyard...\\t
There is an Ogre camp nearby. Ogres are notorious mercenaries, and so you can now recruit a unit of these hungry monsters.

The Tome warns me… Another makes his play against Be'lakor. They have collected four Daemon Prince souls and prepare to cross the gulf to reach the Forge of Souls before us. Ursun is ours to claim, not theirs!\\n\\nWe must intercept them at once. I have used the lore of the Tome to hasten our route.

If we do not reach the Forge of Souls in time, the Chaos God of Shadows will ascend. Time is running short – prepare your armies, enter the Realm of Chaos and reach the Forge of Souls before it is too late!

The Tome of Fates flares. It sends me a grave warning that we must act soon. Using the Daemonic machinery within the Forge of Souls fuelled by the remnants of Ursun, Be'lakor feasts! Where one God dies another shall be born. The Chaos God of Shadows…\\n\\nBe'lakor cannot be allowed to ascend for all will fear his wrath, whether Daemon or mortal!
We have but moments before Be'lakor becomes a God and dooms us all. The Tome is adamant: there is no other fate unless we move to stop him at the Forge of Souls… This is my last warning. Act now.

Your trial within the Realm of Chaos has ended in failure. The Tome of Fates hungers yet we have no Daemon Prince soul to feed it. Yet its pages show me that your rivals have managed to harvest a soul for themselves.\\n\\nWithout the souls, Be'lakor will remain out of reach. We must return to the Realm of Chaos at the next opportunity...
Our goal is clear. To find the lost sister, we must hear the God-Bear's testament before he passes into myth.
Our goal is clear. The Daemon Prince must harness Ursun's power and claim the mantle of a God. I have brokered a pact and will guide him to his desire.
Our goal is to take the head of the God-Bear – a worthy trophy for the Skull Throne.
Our goal is to rescue Ursun, the God-Bear of Kislev, from the clutches of Be'lakor. After fraught bargaining, my price is agreed and I will do all I can to guide the Kislevites to their lost God.
Our goal is to harvest the God-Bear's corpse, the perfect specimen to create the most unholy of plagues, the God-Pox.
Our goal is to claim Ursun. The Ogres will eat their weight in God-flesh, and throw the leftovers into the Great Maw!
Our task is to reap the sorrow of a dying God. Ursun's anguish collected and treasured for eternity.
Our goal is the eyes of the God-Bear – for a God's sight has the power to see all.

To trespass upon the Chaos Realms is to step into a nightmare. Four domains ruled by their cruel masters: Nurgle, the Master of Plagues; Slaanesh, the Lord of Excess; Tzeentch, the Changer of Ways; and Khorne, the Blood God.\\n\\nWe must visit each realm and steal a soul from a Daemon Prince. For it is these souls – one from each of the great powers, merged together – that shall light the hidden path to the Forge.
You have been defeated.\\n\\nBut the Tome of Fates glows bright. Agitated. It is not done with us yet. Ready your army for we must thwart the Dark Master and prevent his ascension at all costs.

We look upon the mortal lands once more having ventured into the Realm of Chaos.\\n\\nThe Tome of Fates thrums with the power of the twisted soul trapped in its pages. To reach the Forge of Souls we require three more.\\n\\nWe are not the only ones who seek the dying God. They employ their own methods to cross the veil into the Realm of Chaos. We must act with haste.

The Tome of Fates is sated. We have our first Daemon Prince soul. There is little time to revel in the glory of what we have achieved, for we require three more souls if we are to illuminate the Bridge of Shadows and reach the Dark Master in his lair at the Forge of Souls.

We have the final soul required to illuminate the path of the Forge. Yet events overtake us, great one. The God-Bear is dead – he will roar no more and reality itself can no longer be contained. Rifts tear through the veil and Daemons flood the mortal world.\\n\\nThis was always part of Be'lakor's plan. He ascends to Godhood... there is no place for us in his grand vision. He must be stopped.

We look upon the mortal lands once again having ventured into the Realm of Chaos.\\n\\nBut we return empty-handed. The Tome of Fates requires the twisted souls of Daemon Princes if we are to illuminate the hidden path to the Forge, where Be'lakor lurks.\\n\\nWe are not the only ones who seek the dying God. They employ their own methods to cross the veil into the Realm of Chaos. We must act with haste.

Good! Another soul is ours, contained within the Tome of Fates.\\n\\nIt would be much easier if we could collect the essence of any Daemon, but a true soul only comes from those with mortal origins. That is why we must slay Daemon Princes, for their soul-stuff – no matter how wretched – comes from a creature that was once mortal.\\n\\nSo, to complete this great task, we must hunt down two more Daemonic Princelings.

A third soul is now lies fettered in the pages of my book. Yet Be'lakor, previously consumed by his own machinations, now strikes out at the threats arrayed against him!\\n\\nGears turn in the Forge of Souls once more, and the Dark Master sends forth armies of Soul Grinders under his command. We must be ready, for they will surely come against us.

The Tome of Fates calls to me, foretelling of a way to elude the maelstrom and enter the Realm of Chaos… The dying God will roar again!\\n\\nWe must prepare! Muster an army that can withstand the terrors you shall face.

The Tome of Fates knows all! The rifts are our opportunity to reach the Chaos Realms. Now, I truly earn my fee!\\n\\nAnd yet, a gateway opens both ways…\\n\\nWhile we may traverse the rifts to enter the Realm of Chaos, or even be transported to far flung areas of this world... we must close the gateways not required or the Daemontide that flows forth will lay your lands in Ruin!

Ah, the Tome flickers to life; fates will clash, Ursun will roar again!\\n\\nThe power it shall unleash will see more rifts open. Be wary of Daemons escaping these portals, however, they also present an opportunity to slip into the Realm of Chaos.
The Tome of Fates feels a frisson of power in the air! The God-Bear will howl again, its pain ripping the fabric of reality, creating rifts once more.

The Tome of Fates warns that a roar from Ursun is coming. Prepare your armies to defend from Daemonic incursion, gird your most powerful army to travel across the void and into the Realm of Chaos!\\n\\nThe roar comes soon…
The God-Bear's roar is imminent. Its power will open more rifts… yet it is weaker than before. It seems Ursun does indeed wane.

I said its name. The skies rained with blood as a Greater Daemon of Khorne emerged from the Screaming Chasm. Great wings carried it over the edge and the ground shook as the Bloodthirster landed beside me.\\n\\nSkulls dropped from the sky. Each one screamed in agony as they fell into the Chasm, forming a bridge.\\n\\nMy brother approached. Loyal Gerik, he trusted me when others would not. Protected me when others could not. He feared the Daemon.

My brother’s lifeless body fell to the ground. The Bloodthirster roared as he threw Gerik’s screaming skull onto the bridge. I crossed the Chasm, the Daemon beside me. My army wavered, yet followed, fearing my wrath.
Nurgle's champions spread their pestilence to your legions. Those that survive such a blessing will be 'gifted'.
The Ruinous Powers demand a large sacrifice of blood. The altars must be drenched in it or we will suffer a loss of favour!
The enemy has unearthed and purged one of our cults. We will recover, but the coven lost some potential influencers that should have served our cause for years to come.
The champions of the Dark Gods are many; one comes to us, ready to serve so he may be rewarded and elevated. Use him, but make sure he knows his place, and the consequences of failure.
The Gods look upon the hordes and are pleased… such is the capricious nature of Chaos.
The Gods look upon the hordes and are angry… such is the fickle power of Chaos.
Khorne is not always a bloodthirsty killer, he occasionally recognises and respects martial prowess in his opponents. He sees it on one of our foes.
War has broken out between rival tribes of the horde. An example must be made to ensure the Marauders will only fight what our Master's desire.
A deadly spell has been unleashed onto the world, sending the Chaos Sorcerer and any in his immediate vicinity back into the Realm of Chaos.

While the Gods seem happy with the strength of our sword arms, they sense weakness should we confront an arcane foe. They have sent us a Chaos Sorcerer - ensure he does our bidding, and not the other way around!
In preparation for the slaughter to come, Tzeentch has favoured one of our champions with a gift.
One of the legendary harems of Slaanesh has been discovered. Your army may be some time…
Grandfather Nurgle has taken an interest in our exploits - he has been generous with his blessings.
The grim skull-adorned temples that dot the land grow restless with power. We should use this event to our advantage!
A plot of the Great Changer has come to fruition, the seeds of which were sown centuries ago. This will aid our cause.
As an almighty storm darkens the skies, the Shaggoths and their kin are roused and ready to honour their ancient pact with the Chaos Gods.
As dawn breaks, and our followers rouse from their dwindling campfires, they discover many of their fellow tribesmen have been turned to mewling spawn. It is a blessing of the Dark Powers!
A terrible nexus of vortices sets down and ravages through the tribes - the Gods are angry!

The favour of the Chaos Gods is fickle. No Lord or even the Everchosen remain in the eyes of the Dark Powers forever. There are always others who aspire to take your place, and they plot and scheme to overthrow you at every opportunity!

Many conflicts are won or lost on the strength of the first, vicious charge. Men are sent flying from the battlefield, often in pieces, even before the savagery of melee begins. A well-timed charge shatters enemy morale, as well as bodies. Blood and sweat may coat the victors, but victory is always painted in colours such as these. Those at the head of the charge seek ever greater thrills, ever more bloodshed. As the battles become bigger, the body count grows higher and the trickles of blood become ever-flowing rivers of red.

The world yields to those who master the Winds of Magic. Great bolts from the heavens scour souls from bodies, whilst raging torrents of fire rend the very flesh from bone. Magic can rip enemies into a dozen pieces or leave nothing but an ugly bloodstain where once they stood. The power granted by the cataclysm, many eons ago, can be harnessed now to bring ruin and destruction upon our enemies. All those who feel the pull of Magic feel it grow as the world festers under Chaos’ Ruinous gaze; their need to ravage grows stronger and stronger by the hour.

Battle is a blood-soaked affair. Limbs severed, bones exposed; men left for dead in the cruor-soaked fields amongst scores of fallen friends and enemies. Strong weapons, forged with time, sweat and expertise, mark the difference between victory and defeat. A good sword cuts clean through bone, severing heads and limbs, where lesser weapons will merely maim. As instability grows across the world, so too does man’s bloodlust and his desire for war and carnage on an ever-grander scale.

A brutish Gor - a pretender and nothing more - challenges the chieftain of the brayherd. The young-horn will pay for such folly - their horns adorning banners, and their hearts offered to the Dark Gods.

Striding through the twisted network of beast-paths, the herds happen across an immense and ancient herdstone. Carved with mysterious runes, the stone records many forbidden and lost ways of Cloven Ones.
The ongoing slaughter draws nearby Minotaur tribes. They hunger for blood and battle.
Your herds came across a chapel of the mewling man-scum hammer king and smeared it with filth and the bones of its own priests. Such blasphemy stokes the fear in those who follow such a feeble deity.
The Gods look upon the warherds and are pleased… Such is the capricious nature of Chaos.
The Gods look upon the warherds and are angry… Such is the fickle power of Chaos.
The Granter of Savage Hate sees our warherd for a brief moment, blessing the Gors with an exceptionally ruthless gift.
A Bray-Shaman is cast aside while trying to dominate a Cygor. The cloven mage will recover but is wounded for now.
Pleased by the terrible deeds sewn by the bastard sons of Chaos, the Ruinous Powers reward one of their behorned champions with a boon.
The Granter of Savage Hate demands more slaughter! The Blood God imbues the warherd with a proportion of his rage.

The Centigors raid a nearby winery, bringing back barrels of suspicious liquid. The herd gathers and drinks... only to suffer a hellish hangover! No wonder it is only foppish man-filth and the stinking elf-kin that drink such rot!
The Centigors raid a nearby brewery, bringing back barrels of mannish beer. The herd gathers to slake their thirst.

A black-hobbed crow flies across the sky. In its wake come the beasts - reptiles, mewling cats, frenzied cattle, boars and others driven mad by something they have witnessed deep in the forest. The Famine-fiend stalks the land, emerging from the woods to leaving nothing but barren wastes and withered crops in his wake - for that is Slugtongue's curse.

Mankind has fallen. Their civilisation has been crushed; stamped under hoof and shattered. The Gods will be pleased, for their children have done well, but what now for the Cloven Ones? There is still much to do. While mankind’s sovereigns have been slaughtered and their champion’s corpses tossed on a raging pyre, the remnants of this pitiful race still live. It is decreed: all traces of man, and his limp allies, should be despoiled. Take the blood-spattered Banner of the Fallen Kings - a glorious reminder of our victory - and finish the cull!
The harbinger comes; storms wrack the forests in its wake. The Herdstones glow with dread and the Winds of Magic grow strong.
The brayherds gather around the herdstone in an orgy of bloody greed - feasting on captives and the weaker runts of the herd. The Gors will be sated and healthy for some time.
Giants do not make common cause with the brayherds, but if the titans are wandering close by, they join in the slaughter - tempted by snacking on Ungor!

Back when Vlad first held Castle Drakenhof - having taken it from the mad count, Otto von Drak - he would hold the most notorious parties. Guests would come in costume with their faces hidden behind bejewelled masks. Music and dancing earlier in the evening would give way to darker and carnal pursuits later on.\\n\\nVlad hosts another masqued ball, the first for centuries, where Vampires and willing mortal nobles will receive a smidgen of power in return for their eternal servitude. It is a deal that can only favour the first von Carstein...

The spirits that refuse to leave the mortal plane remain in the forest, fusing with living trees to become Treemen. These warriors are mighty and terrifying, yet each one that leaves the forest to fight weakens it, if only temporarily.

The forest provides for those who do it great service. The Lords and Ladies of the realms of Athel Loren are chosen nobility, provided for greatly by the spirits of the forest. Those who work in more insalubrious capacities are still offered succour by the woods, for their all-the-same important service to the realm.

The Wood Elves of the Moonspring Glades, ever interested in unearthing truths about their ancestry, have struck upon a trove of information, buried deep beneath the forest. The scriptures they have uncovered seem to date all the way back to the Great Voyage, when the Elves travelled from Ulthuan and established themselves in Athel Loren. The information contained therein will help shape the future of all Asrai...

The Eternal Realms of Athel Loren are led by great Lords and Ladies, who in turn feel a responsibility for their Elven subjects. Their spirits, and the spirits of the forest, must be kept appeased. And so it is they have thrown great and lavish masques, across the realms, to better bring together the forest and the Asrai. Of course, such ventures are never, ever cheap...

The greatest shock for the Asrai was the discovery that they were not alone in the forests - the Beastmen hordes had made squalid dens amongst the trees. For centuries the two have fought for ownership of the woods. Long have they fought, with not even the climactic Battle of Anguish enough to cease the conflict...

The Dreaming Woods, Athel Caiellin, is a forbidden place ruled by the worshippers of Slaanesh. To travel there is to flirt with madness and temptation, and those that emerge are either wracked by lunacy, or forged by the crucible of their experiences. This one has walked through the fires of insanity, and found an ethereal strength on the other side...

There is one domain of Athel Loren regarded as the home of the smiths; the Forge of Starlight. Beneath these noisome and industrious boughs, the undisputed master armourers ply their craft with unfaltering excellence. The weapons created here not only provide a literal edge in battle, but improve the morale of those wielding them simply by their knowing where they came from.

The Lords and Ladies of Athel Loren gather every so often to discuss and determine the future of the Asrai. Their word, once the debate is concluded, is proclaimed throughout the forests and enacted immediately. At this moment, they have decided that more funds are required if Athel Loren is to prosper...

As Spring finally bursts forth across Athel Loren, the deep chills of Winter retreat and life is given free reign once more. The forests bloom, verdant and lively. The boughs spread, the vines grow, and life explodes from the Deepwood once more…

The chill of Winter has passed, and the dew-soaked branches of Spring have begun to blossom. The Asrai allow themselves a moment of rest within Athel Loren. As the forest regenerates, so too do the Wood Elves…

At the height of the season of growth, the forests of Athel Loren push rebelliously past the Waystone fence and into the tracts of heath and scrub that border the mystical woods. Such boundless enthusiasm is admirable, but equilibrium must be maintained. All Asrai are predisposed in the management of the forest; things may move a little slower until Athel Loren is... curtailed.

Against the boundaries of the Waystone fence, interlopers have come with their weapons of war. They brought destruction and vandalism to Athel Loren, before retreating like craven cowards when the forest stirred. Athel Loren demands vengeance, and would have you exact it.

Those Waywatchers that become attuned to the forest's every motion soon find they prefer the company of the trees to their own kindred. These 'Waystalkers' are the most expert of hunters, singularly dedicated to the whims of Athel Loren…

The Branchwraiths are no friends to the Asrai, and so openly plot against them when given the opportunity. However, greater evils still stalk amongst the trees; if the Branchwraiths are to wreak their havoc upon the woods, they must first be purged.

With Belegar's forces in control of the area, an extensive search is carried out. Urk trails are quickly found that lead to previously hidden entrances to the Underway. Such portals are new, and far beyond the skills of the Greenskins to create, but are undoubtedly in use by their sworn enemies. Belegar doesn't like this deduction at all - it suggests coercion or, at the worst, even treason. Either fate is a great sin in the eyes of the Ancestors.

A Goblin eagerly accepts the bribe and details where the false prophet is currently hidden. Wurrzag listens and then hands over the reward. The gobbo’s eyes light up at seeing all the booty. Such elation is short-lived though, as Wurrzag loudly proclaims to his followers that any who knew this information but withheld it for gain are clearly enemies of Mork and Gork… That night Wurrzag’s most fervent followers eat roasted, bribed gobbo...
This hunting season has been one of uncommonly high volume - nobles simply cannot get enough of the game. Whilst this has kept the aristocracy appeased, farms and villages have felt the pinch.

Although they tried to hide it, the peasants of a nearby village were discovered with traces of a new, foul pox. To keep it from spreading, the entire village was swiftly burned to cinders; the potential crisis has been averted.

To impress upon visiting aristocrats to our fair cities, our merchants showered lavish products upon them at discounted prices. Although this affected their profits, the quality of their goods has been praised the world over.
Churches and chapels across the realm are reporting healthy numbers of worshippers. Those close to the Enchantress say that she is pleased; if so, then surely the Lady herself is also?

The most recent tourney was heralded as a great success; violence, bloodshed and feasting galore! It has been many days, yet people are still abuzz at the grandeur of it all. Truly, Bretonnia is blessed.
The noblemen continually have innovative and expansive ideas for how to improve and grow our cities; their wondrous minds give birth to a revolution in construction!

Another season, another feast. No other kingdom in the Old World can lay claim to banquets so great. Such was the magnificence, that there is much left over to give to our artisans in gratitude for their endless hard work.

When a Knight cheats at a tournament, it demeans not only himself, but the very ideals of a chivalric Bretonnia. One of our most heralded Knights has been caught locking himself to his horse, preventing his dismount in the joust. Truly, he brings shame upon us all.

There is no denying that the Knight is the pinnacle of the chivalric ideal, but arrogance must never get the better of honour. Some Knights, unfortunately, enjoy basking in their own glory a little too much…
The farmland peasants have been growing restless and rowdy, complaining about their lot in life. They spoke the Vow of Duty, did they not? Then their quarrelsome tone is nothing less than blasphemy.

Many hours' worth of toil, and many coffers' worth of coin have been poured into the restoration of the Grail Monastery. Now, returned to its former glory, nobles have rushed to send their children there to learn from Bretonnia's most prestigious academics.

A churlish peasant had the snivelling gall to throw a noble from his horse, in retaliation for an apparent 'slight' against his family. He has, naturally, been hanged by the neck until dead, so that nobody else thinks to act rebelliously.
Having completed their current Vow, this character may now go on to make a new pledge towards their next one!
Having completed their current Troth, this character may now go on to make a new pledge towards their next one!

Your people live in fear, for evil stalks fair Bretonnia. The Greenskins that infest the mountains and forests harass and raid the surrounding villages with ever-greater violence. Now they mass in the hills the people fear a greater incursion – control is decreasing across the land as a result. Hold out, if you think the kingdom robust enough – in the hope that they tire and skulk back to their hideouts – or lead a force to destroy their settlements, end their attacks and wipe them out for good.

The winds blow ever fierce and cold in the North, but on this day the gale's bite is unusually strong.  Such harshness serves only to strengthen the resolve of your warriors, and as their wills harden so do their very hides - their skin becomes as tough as stone. Honour this gift and the Gods who have bestowed it. Spill blood in their names!

The Kislevites dare to march on the North! The men of their Bear army destroy your shrines and throw down your offerings. This affront has your shamans raging and cursing the southerners. There is only one response to such desecration: you will spill their blood and take their wealth as offerings to the Gods!

A savage storm strikes in the night. Its violent winds, laced with shards of ice that slice though the hardest metal, have scythed through your forces. Your warriors awaken to discover that some of the strongest have failed to withstand the wrath of the Gods, and been shredded by the storm's unearthly might.

To the many bitter trials you must endure is added a new and unexpected one: the sky itself rains blood on your army! But while lesser men might curse or cower your ferocious warriors see this for the sign from the Gods that it is. They welcome the bloody rain, just as they welcome the chance to bathe in the blood of your enemies.

What new test is this? The very ground has opened up beneath your Warhird and swallowed up several of your champions. They must have been weak! Those warriors who remain and did not incur such displeasure must truly be the Chosen of the Gods. They will make your enemies tremble!

As your forces pass through lands barren of life, they see a rare sight: a mighty herd of War Mammoths, migrating across the icy wastes. They are not easy prey, but your men are ruthless and skilled hunters. Soon the air is thick with panicked trumpeting and heavy with the sweet scent of blood. Then, after the slaughter: the feast. Fresh meat brings new strength to your warhird!

Your raiders take what they want from those they attack, but recent pillage has included little that can serve as food. At the same time, game is sparse in the north; you send out hunting parties but they return with nothing to show for their efforts. Your men are tough but when a warrior's belly is empty, his strength ebbs.

This night, no darkness comes to the vastness of the North. Instead the sun shines bright, remaining high in the sky above. It can only be a sign from the Gods, telling you to urge your men on to greater savagery and plunder. None shall rest until darkness returns!

Your raiders have ventured far, and now bring back unexpected tidings. Deep in the deserts of the far south they found strangeness as well as plunder: they speak of death that is not final, and of walking skeletons, and they have returned with a most unusual prize: a crown of gold.

As your raiders ply the chill seas in search of fresh lands to plunder, all at once the cold grows greater still. In an instant, the sea all around transforms to unforgiving ice! Yet even so, your men's ship remains whole and undamaged, its path clear. This must be a sign from the Gods! They give you their dark blessing in your endevours, keeping the seaways clear for you to plunder new lands.

Your people have unearthed a rift in your lands, linking it to the realm of the Gods themselves! The blood you have spilt has indeed won their favour, for now your warriors can soak up divine power directly from this rift, restoring their vitality, closing their wounds and infusing them with new strength to bring further death and destruction to your enemies.

Amongst the plunder snatched from the soft southern lands, your men have brought back useless and distracting trinkets with no obvious function. Rather than discarding such wastes of time and effort in favour of further bloodying their blades to honour the Gods, some of your warriors are taking an interest in these foolish contraptions.

The elite of your Marauder Hunters were sent out into the mountains to search for the Chaos Frost Dragon, but none returned! Maybe the weather was just too unforgiving, even for hardened warriors like them. Or perhaps they found the target – or it found them, rather – and fell victim to it. Still, the hunt must be seen through. You immediately send out word that you are offering a considerable bounty to anyone who can lead you to Frigustrex’s location or tell you of its whereabouts.

Having accumulated the funds the Shaman demanded, you pay his fee. There is always the chance that he will double-cross you or fail to deliver what he promises, but it doesn’t matter anyway – you can always execute him later and retrieve the gold if needed. With the job now paid for, the Shaman scurries out of his hut.
The payment for the slave is made and he is now your rightful property. The information you seek can now be obtained!

Your Hero proves himself to be very capable, successfully returning and dumping the hog-tied Bretonnian herb collector at your feet, scared but alive. The Goblins were about to make stew out of him, but your Hero was able to cause a distraction and rescue him, snatching the naked prisoner right out of the large man-sized cauldron they had placed him in to be boiled alive. Your opportunistic servant also managed to grab some of the Goblins’ loot on his way out, making the mission more than worthwhile.

The Greenskins are famous for having all manner of monstrosities in their despicable ranks, including the lumbering Giants that follow them to feast in battle. Having heard of one very belligerent Giant called Blorgar the Mad Titan terrorising the Grey Mountains, you set out to slay the leviathan for a great sacrifice, for what can be more impressive than bringing down a legendary descendant of the long-forgotten Sky-Titans?\\n\\nOnce you’d arrived in the Grey Mountains, however, Blorgar was nowhere to be seen. The only chance of gaining any useful information of the Giant’s whereabouts lay with a Bretonnian herb collector who’d allegedly stumbled upon an underground lair while spelunking nearby. Unfortunately this Bretonnian had been taken hostage by some nasty Goblins on a recent raid. The importance of the information known to him is crucial to complete the hunt, so a Hero was sent into the gobbos' camp to steal him back.\\n\\nYour servant dumps the hog-tied Bretonnian herb collector at your feet, along with some loot he managed to steal on his way out.

Now that you’ve raised the money for the greedy green cretins, they give up the Bretonnian hostage to you. Again, you consider killing them for their insolence, but before you can give the order to slaughter them they’ve high-tailed it into the mountains with their payment. Never mind - you’ve got what you paid for and now you have a hunt to finish.
A Dwarf is never content to part with gold, but the upgraded workshops will allow this labour to proceed.
Sending supplies and treasure to the fugitives secures a treaty of co-operation with them. Thorgrim can now call on their aid should he need it.

The populace in one of your settlements is gradually vanishing! On certain nights, whole ghettos or districts are left abandoned - the only clue for the remaining denizens is a triangular symbol daubed on a nearby gate or wall…

Arcane Fulcrums are terrible, complex and eldritch monoliths whose nature and function have puzzled the finest minds for millennia. Should a magic-user stand at the pinnacle of the one found here then his powers will be greatly enhanced.
The herds of Chaos are active. The Beastmen emerge from the forests and raid your more-isolated settlements, bringing ruin and taking captives.
The weather in these lands is rarely governed by the seasons, and now a blizzard of icy shards has come scything down from the mountains. Those not prepared will die.
This world breeds tough men; some of whom can also be bitter, cruel and greedy. They mob together in gangs of brigands to prey upon travellers and traders.
The most powerful of all enchantments, known as Cataclysm Spells, can only be cast during or in the wake of a Storm of Magic. Such a destructive spell has been unleashed upon your realm…

A pride of monstrous Chimerae has flown down from the mountain reaches - or displaced by some other foul threat - and are causing havoc amongst the populace. It will be some time before they can be removed!
Revere the gods for we need their favour. Yet some fools - insurgents or traitors - are destroying shrines. Doing so risks incurring a holy wrath on us all.
The cruel sun bakes the lands - Stromfels, God of Storms, punishes us. The people grow restless as water and food diminish.
The drought continues. Water has become so scarce it is now worth more than gold or Warpstone! Only those with true power are spared this privation.
The gods rage and so the ground shakes. Buildings collapse, statuary fall and our followers die in the rubble or are taken by the dwellers below.
Portents of doom cloud this settlement and so many of its inhabitants flee to seek sanctuary - or a change in fortunes - elsewhere.
The luring grin of Morrslieb is visible; it dominates the night sky and those who look up at it are said to go insane or driven to murderous rage. Order must be restored.
Food is scarce. The foetid hand of Nurgle is no doubt involved, causing crops to wither, milk to sour and game to diminish. Another source of sustenance must be found.
Your followers praise their leader and pray to the gods for their continuing support. They hold a great feast in your honour.
Aqshy's kiss has visited us! The settlement is ablaze! Your followers are flooding the crowded streets, trying to escape a horrible burning death.
Mannslieb's orbit strains and the lands flood, causing watery devastation in its wake…
The gods of your enemies have directly intervened in our interests. Sowing destruction across our realm, how do we confront a god's wrath?
Appease your neighbours or keep hostile ones at bay, for now at least. This will keep our borders stable and allow us to strike at enemies further afield.
Good! Distract your people with brutish games. Crowds flock to the fighting pits and arenas to revel in the violence and forget their woes for a time.
Our troops are lost. Whether this is due to some nefarious scheme, Grey Magic enchantment, or simple incompetence is irrelevant - they must retrace their steps and lose time.
A vile disease, birthed by Grandfather Nurgle or one of his foul minions, is sweeping across the population. We can only hope it is one of his less successful concoctions!
The pirate fleets of Sartosa travel far and wide looking for bounty. Now they come across your trade routes and are attacking our ships.
There is a distinct lack of able and willing bodies to join your forces for the ongoing wars. Your press gangers, recruiters or straight-up kidnappers are struggling to find "volunteers".

As the Blood God knows all too well, war is a meat grinder that constantly requires fresh supplies, which means recruits are not always easy to come by. On this rare occasion, however, there is a glut of bodies, ready and willing to join the fray.
Everyday more of your followers flock to the city in fear that some terrible peril or enemy horde will murder them without the protection of its walls.
The lands are haunted - spirits and ghosts of dead warriors, victims of battles long-since fought - harass and frighten our warriors. This is a bad omen.
A gigantic, floating, sea fortress has been spotted off the coast. And wherever it is seen, coastal settlements have been raided - those not slain outright carried off to some dread fate.
The coming of the End Times can make allies of bitter enemies and strengthen the bonds of existing friendships.
Morrslieb, the dreaded moon of ill omens, hangs mournfully large in the sky. Its sickly green glow spreads across your realm - a portent of death and dismay.
One of the great mountains of the Old World has erupted, bringing about a fiery hell. Even the waters boil and everything within proximity to the volcano has been reduced to ashes.
No matter your dominance of the realms, there will also be creatures that prowl the forests or roam the plains. One of these beasts is attacking and feeding upon your people.

Like malevolent hail, chunks of Warpstone are falling from the sky in certain parts of your realm. Those that survive the onslaught are far from safe or the mutating effects of the Chaos stuff that now scatters the ground.

A map has been discovered of the fabled lost Dwarfhold of Karak Zorn. Should Karak Zorn ever be reclaimed for the Karaz Ankor it would be a great triumph in the Age of Reckoning. A large expedition is organised, at great cost and resources.
A Reckoner visits to inspect the Hold's books and ensure proper tribute is being paid to the High King. However, his laborious scrutiny has uncovered some creative accounting…
One of the oldest entries in this Dwarfhold's Book of Grudges has been struck out. A great feast is held to celebrate!

The Hold's brewery has run dry. For the Dawi, this is a disaster! The Brewmaster has already withdrawn in shame, and the Dwarfs have been forced to import weak, mannish brews in the interim. Morale is at an all-time low.
Clan honour has been invoked! Tributes and Clans-Dwarfs must be gathered, some slight or greater grudge has been committed against the Clan and the offenders must pay!
The Clans are not happy - well, they never are - but they are particularly grumpy at the moment. Grumbling Clan Lords are meeting in moots and muttering about your reign.

Wanaz - Clanless Dwarfs - have come to the Hold hoping for sanctuary despite the shame such charity will bring upon their ancestors. A small lessening of our honour by accepting them is made up for with a boost to population numbers.
A Chaos Dragon is attacking the Hold. The cursed Drakk will eventually be fended off by the Dwarfhold's considerable defences, but not before substantial loss of Dawi life.
The kvinn (Khazalid for lady) population of the Hold have denounced the quality of male stock from which to choose a husband. As a result, the majority of maidens have left in search of fresh beards.
A seam of star metal, that rarest and most sought-after of all elements - Gromril - has been discovered close to the Dwarfhold. Refining it will bring prestige and great wealth.

The powerful Engineers' Guild has sent one of their top tinkerers to inspect this Hold's workshops after hearing concerning rumours of "innovation". On his arrival he is so impressed with the work done he decides to stay.
The Guilds - fractious and intransigent institutions - have, for once, aligned with each other and are in full support of your rule. Trade will surely prosper!
A part of the Dwarfhold, a lost area under the clutches of urks for many years, has been reclaimed. The Clans are already setting up undertakings in the new areas.
Amidst the banging of tankards on the feasting tables, and raucous cheers and ribald chants, a storied hero of the Hold is risen up to the rank of Thane.

The Rik has sealed the Dwarfhold - the great bar lays across its mountain doors and in the deeps the iron gates have come crashing down, severing the Underway. Why the Lord would do this is as yet a mystery!
The Karak's landing pads and Gyrocopter fleet have been destroyed in a daring operation! The damned urks! It will be sometime before the aircorps can be restored.

The Hold's Slayers are summoned to Karak Kadrin to worship at the foot of Grimnir's Statue and then onto a great pilgrimage to seek out their death. To try and stop it risks forcing them to break their oath - no Dwarf would ever consider that!
The Miners would dig to the core of the world if they could, but this time they may have tunnelled too far, bore too deep into the roots of the mountain, for something stirs, something dreadful…
Ancient underground foes attack! They must be stopped or we risk losing another stronghold to their vile encroachment.

A close ally of yours has been shamed - a record has been unearthed concerning his ancestor reneging on an oath. The sins of past generations must be answered by the living, and so he has given up his wealth and status to take the Slayer Oath.
Repairs to a crucial part of the Underway have been completed, but at a great cost to the Hold's treasury. It is a price worth paying, as the Underway is key to the resurgence of the Karaz Ankor.

Upon completion of his 200 years service as an apprentice to a Runelord, a Runesmith has left his master, enquired about the sacred forges in the Hold and whether he could have the honour of lighting them again.

A Dwarf Engineer and his surroundings have been immolated as he was experimenting with the potency of black powder. Underground fires are something the Dawi are used to dealing with, although significant damage was still sustained.
The Graf who holds sway over this region is offended that the Emperor did not invite him to the grand feast of Sigmarzeit. Diplomacy with them will be a little rocky for a while.

The military complex of the Empire is a strange beast with no centralised standing army. The Grafs and Electors control their own men but even so, their Captains may favour one leader over another as in the case of this Captain publicly supporting you.

It has long been rumoured that Stirland's proximity to Sylvania means its courts are susceptible to Vampire infiltration. Our spies suspect such an occurrence, for Stirland is being aggressive to us. The influence of the von Carsteins is surely to blame.

The Twin-Tailed Comet arcs across the sky, a portent of great events. The Grand Theogonist has decreed this to be a good omen. Your warriors are elated that Sigmar looks upon them, and gird themselves for war.

The Twin-Tailed Comet arcs across the sky, a portent of great events. The Grand Theogonist has decreed this to be an ill omen. The comet is a warning that dire events are about to unfold, so your warriors are shaken and wary.

Black powder should be kept dry and away from open flames until used in cannons and such. Of course, it needs to be stored somewhere, just as long as no careless fool walks into the store with a torch or lantern…
The seeds of Heresy is suspected in one of our settlements. The Grand Theogonist has released a Witch Hunter and charged him to root out the Chaos taint!

A previously hostile Elector Count is ready to sue for peace. The Electors are political animals, so it is doubtful this gesture is motivated by selfless reasons, more likely another agenda is at play.

The appetites of the Halflings are legendary, but now they have nothing left to fill their hotpots. Hisme Stoutheart, Elder of the Moot, is demanding food be shipped in: "We'll make cutbacks, so we only need enough for three courses per meal."
You have the backing of the Cult of Sigmar. The Warrior Priests preach in the temples and on the battlefields of your divine right to the throne, and so flock to your banner.

This local noble has always held a deep dislike of Karl Franz, ever since they courted the same girl a few years back. Needless to say, the Prince of Altdorf won the maiden's heart, further hardening the rival's hatred.
The smallfolk have barricaded themselves in their homes, for this is the dread night of mysteries - when both moons are seen in the night sky and the dead awake to drag the living to hell…
The rumour-smiths tell us that, in the court and along the verandas of Altdorf, our 'loyal' nobles plot your downfall. Better to nip this in the bud before malfeasance blossoms.
Ogres from the eastern kingdoms have come on the pretence of looking for work, but instead are causing quite a lot of bother, damage, and have eaten a few of the Watch as well…

Count Hertwig of Ostermark has declared his province free of the 'Emperor's Yoke'. Ostermark is now an independent nation, the Elector Count has announced. Apparently, envoys are already in the courts of Bretonnia and Marienburg. Do not rule out the politicking of the Burgomeisters in this. If so, they must be punished!
A large gathering of Flagellants combined with the usual rabble-rousers and malcontents have inflamed a riot. This will need halting or it may spread to other settlements.

A retired physician has been discovered to be a practising Necromancer. It seems the corpses he used to collect were for more than simply anatomical study! He must be stopped before he summons forth further minions!

An entire city district has been ransacked by unknown assailants said to have emerged from the sewers. Property has been destroyed and entire families have vanished - dragged into the sewers by hooded Daemons, if you believe the rumour-smiths...
More than a mere raid, the brayherds of the Beastmen are migrating across the world, and anything - or anyone - in their way is being destroyed.
All prattling, petty merchants are the same - they decry taxes and whinge how bureaucracy stifles trade. Now the Burgomeisters demand tax relief or will halt supplies.
The Colleges of Magic rarely agree, but on this occasion they are aligned and will support you. A Battle Wizard is sent to accompany your forces.

Countess Emmanuelle von Liebewitz is a shrewd political player. She has made it known that, while not personal, she does not support your cause. Nuln and Wissenland will remain hostile to you for the foreseeable future.

In a speech given when Emperor Luitpold still held the throne, Franz was heard to say how much he dislikes this region. It is a speech that has come back to haunt him, for the residents here certainly haven't forgotten his words.

A bitter disagreement has come about between Ostland and Hochland over who invented the famous long rifle! Ages-old resentments have come to the surface, and, due to our alliance with Ostland, Hochland remain highly suspicious of our intentions.

A bitter disagreement has come about between Ostland and Hochland over who invented the famous long rifle! Ages-old resentments have come to the surface, and, due to our alliance with Hochland, Ostland view us in an extremely hostile light.

A cult of Taal within Talabheim has grown in power and fermented resentment over Sigmar's ascendancy, supposedly at Taal's expense. A religious war within the borders of the Empire is now almost a certainty.
In the year 2429 Marienburg seceded from the Empire due to the selfish designs of the Burgomeisters. And now, mere decades later, another province dares to demand the same…

The Prophets of Doom have roused the masses, the disposed, the fanatical… and now a great migration of Flagellants floods the city, choking trade and causing great disharmony among the local populace.

Boris may one day become a great ally... one day. For now, he resents the duly elected Emperor's ascension to the throne. Never a patient man - or one to hide his fury - he will be difficult to appease.
The insidious taint of Chaos is not just found in the north. The Great Changer has many agents and followers working nefarious schemes within the Empire's vast society.
The Badlands are blighted with Morrslieb's attention. The Night Goblins refuse to leave their caves and even your fiercest boyz would rather lurk in the strongholds than fight.

Rebellion is in the air, one of your Bosses has been heard slagging you off over his grog! A few are getting their heads together and muttering. You'll need to assert your dominance sooner rather than later.
Wurrzag, the prancing Shaman of Gork and Mork, visits to bring you good news and the blessing of the Green Godz.
Wurrzag, the prancing Shaman of Gork and Mork, visits to bring you ill omens and the scorn of the Green Godz. You must do something to get back in their favour.

The one thing your kind loves as much as war is poo. You pile it high, building your huts or fashioning it into idols of Gork or Mork. Trouble is, that stuff gets hot when there's a large mound of it, creating a stinky gas which can explode… and has!
A small Dwarfen throng, or 'mob of stunty gitz', in your parlance is attacking a stronghold. They hope to reclaim it for the Karaz Ankor. Fools!
The eyes of one of the Idols has started glowing. Deep growling can also be heard around its stomach. The Shamans are dancing around it, claiming that Mork speaks!
The Goblins are revolting… well, we already knew that, but they are rioting as well. The little gits should be taught a lesson!
A Shaman has been drinking too much grog. While "hammered" he accidentally summoned the Foot of Gork, which promptly trampled all over the encampment.
From the plains, a wandering, lone Greenskin emerges. He's a Shaman, expelled from his previous tribe due to an unfortunate incident "wiv da boss' pet Squig". He's looking for a new master to serve.

This season's harvest of Mad Caps has been disappointing. Then a rampaging Squig ate the few that were left. Without the mushrooms the Night Goblins can't make their infamous brew. Hopefully, the next batch will have a better yield.
After a long, bloody night of curved daggers, an ambitious Goblin has emerged as a Big Boss. He presents himself, ready to do your bidding.

Whilst prancing around a campfire in some bone-jangling, feather-waving dance, your Shaman over-gyrated his hips, tripped over a gobbo and dived headfirst into the fire, getting severely burned. The boyz are disturbed…

The trouble with Goblins is they are sneaky, stabby gits. If you don't keep them in their place they'll get ideas. Now we have a few gobbos trying to take control. The Bosses will put them in their place, but not before they cause mischief.
A swarm of Snotlings blights the region. Despite many Orcs stomping and splatting countless creatures, the Snotlings continue to thrive, consuming everything around!
The warm, damp weather of late has created ideal conditions in the nests and hatcheries of forest spiders. The Great Spider-god is praised for his generosity.
The Squigs have broken out of their pens, causing havoc, eating their handlers and sending the remaining Night Goblins scattering!

A Khan from the Blasted Wastes has crossed through Death Pass and laid waste to parts of your territory. As is typical of their kind, the cowards have fled back across the World's Edge before we could deal with them properly!
Displaced by the Chaos hordes in the north, the Trolls are migrating towards the Badlands, perhaps sensing a dominating presence they can serve?
The Waaagh! ended in failure, its target somehow spared from the spoliations of the belligerent mobs of Orcs and Goblins. The world can breathe a sigh of relief!
The world looked on in horror as the Waaagh! swept over its doomed victims. All shudder in fear of being the next to suffer this cruel fate.
Your Waaagh! failed to raze or occupy the target in the allotted time! The dejected mobs scatter from your armies, incensed at not getting the loot and battle glory they expected.
You have successfully completed the Call to Waaagh! and attained your trophy! The mobs have dispersed – for now. Start building your reputation towards your next Call to Waaagh!!

Your Waaagh! successfully occupied its target! To obtain your trophy, ensure that you still occupy the target when the Call to Waaagh! duration ends. The additional Waaagh! units shall stay to help your armies defend your prize until that time.

Your Waaagh! successfully razed its target! The additional Waaagh! units shall stay with your armies for the remaining duration of the Call to Waaagh! after which you will be awarded your trophy. In the meantime you may continue to use them for your destructive ends.
The Undead legions grow, but not even our master can oversee every battle. More sires are required - another Vampire is needed to help bring about the eternal night.

Necromancers are power-mad, often driven insane by the magicks they dabble in. Occasionally, they forget their place and think to usurp the true masters of Undeath - the Vampires. This Necromancer thinks he is better than us…

Vampire Knights from the Blood Dragon order pass through our lands. Despite our entreatments, they will not fight for us - some foolish notion of honour prevents it. However, they have left us a gift - a blessing of Abhorash on our own cavalry.

The Corpse Carts scour the lands - riding into isolated hamlets and taking corpses fresh and foul, smashing through the gates of Morr's garden to plunder the tombs. And now they return to us, the carts full of flesh to be reanimated!
There are many Necromancers hiding within mortal society. We must bring them under our thrall, so they may further our aims. Call to them, and see which broken souls answer!
Nyklaus von Carstein has approached us, requesting resources to go on some bizarre quest into a lost sea realm he calls the "Galleon's Graveyard". He will no doubt be resentful if we refuse.

Morr, the God of Death, is a sworn enemy of Nagash and all Undead for we tamper with His so-called holy rules. Where his priests roam they bless the lands and make it harder for our ilk to raise the dead.

A nexus of Dark Magic surrounds us, bolstering our might and breathing unlike into anything you so choose. It is as if Geheimnisnacht is happening every night! We must use this blessing of dark intent while it remains!
Packs of Dire Wolves run rampant to blight the lands of the mortals. But a master must bring his dogs to heel at some point - do that and they will be part of our legions, and a more effective tool.
Morrslieb glows and refuses to leave the sky, even when day should have been summoned. The continuing darkness lends power to our legions as they march ever on!

When Vlad seized control of Sylvania he turned the majority of its destitute nobility, thus ensuring there is always another von Carstein eager to enact his own plans for domination - even at the expense of his so-called siblings.
Even the most cunning of Necromancers or powerful Vampires need cadavers to bring the Undead forth. Supplies have run low here; until fresh corpses can be found, troops will be hard to come by.

The Undead legions are immortal and immune to mortal concerns, such as disease. But the Chaos God Nurgle has a strange sense of humour, and so has blessed the lands with Grave Rot, a blight that quickens the decomposition process, meaning our troops are literally falling apart...

Hexensnacht - the Night of Witches - brings the veil of death ever closer to the mortal realm as the new year arrives. It is a time for the Undead to rise and the smallfolk to lock and bar their doors.

Despite the Vampires' hatred of Nagash, his influence is inextricably linked to all creatures of Undeath. Some say his dread soul is abroad, bound to a lost relic until a vessel can be found. Until then, his whispering can be occasionally heard upon ethereal winds, augmenting Undead puppets with a jerky speed.

The Daughters of Lahmia come to visit upon their Coven Throne. They drink the crimson from fine wine goblets and make veiled threats hidden behind fanged smiles. We must destroy them, but not yet… for now we play amenable hosts.

The Liber Noctus, an ancient text copied directly from scrolls of Nehekhara, has gone missing from our vaults. Such precious knowledge in the hands of a rival Liche will strengthen his power and weaken our own designs.
The still-living smallfolk of our realms have gathered with torches and pitchforks daring to approach our castles with their petty demands! Such an insurgence must not be tolerated!
A Ghoul King has been seen in our realms, and with him run the Crypt Ghouls and all manner of their vile kin. While the Strigoi himself will not bow to your majesty, his minions surely will.
The Wight Kings of old will fight for us providing the proper forms are followed. We know the rituals so let us send our agents to the barrows and call a Wight King forth.

As our power grows, it gains the attention of other foreboding creatures, the wailing hags emerge from their swamp and foetid haunts to join us in the destruction of the living - a Tomb Banshee has come.

While Necromancy and Death Magic are essential to the raising of the dead, there are other forms of magic such as Life and Light that are anathema to such rituals. When Jade and Light Wizards wander, the Undead suffer.

Word has reached us that Vlad von Carstein - the first of the Midnight Aristocracy - and long-since thought slain at the Siege of Altdorf, is abroad. For now these sightings are nothing more than rumours, but should they be true then our plans could be undone, as his ambition overcomes all!
The Holy Order of the Silver Hammer - accursed Witch Hunters - have been sighted in our lands. Be wary of these silver-wielding mortals, for they are Volkmar's puppets!
Count Mannfred pays the Necromancer's price, but has no regrets when he lays eyes on the tome. He recognises it as being one of the nine Books of Nagash, authored by the Great Necromancer himself.
As expected, it is a fortifying drink indeed and now Grombrindal is ready to fight! Bugman sends the White Dwarf on his way with one of his best scouts.
Grombrindal is ready to fight! Bugman sends the White Dwarf on his way with one of his best scouts.
